DOC.HEAD: World's Largest Jewish Organization To Allow Women Members
DOC.TEXT: The world's largest Jewish organization, B'nai Brith International, is setting aside its 147-year history as a predominantly male group and will allow women as full members. Leaders of B'nai Brith and B'nai Brith Women this week reached an agreement that recognizes B'nai B'rith Women as an independent, self-governing organization affiliated with B'nai B'rith. Delegates to the B'nai B'rith biennial convention gathered in Dallas last week. As B'nai B'rith moved in recent years toward admitting women, the future of the separate women's organization has been hotly debated. The agreement defines B'nai B'rith Women as a women's organization and B'nai B'rith as an organization for both men and women. The agreement can be renegotiated after five years. The measure admitting women as full members to B'nai B'rith passed unanimously Tuesday at the convention. Previously, there were individual units of the organization that allowed women members. With the change, about 10,000 new women members to B'nai B'rith are expected. ``We have indeed preserved what we did not want to tear asunder,'' said B'nai B'rith Women president Harriet Horowitz. ``This agreement ends a complicated and tense time in the history of our organizations,'' Ms. Horowitz said. ``It ends a situation that has divided families and created much adverse publicity.'' Retiring B'nai B'rith president Seymour Reich favored admitting the women's group as a full equal. The agreement must be ratified by the B'nai B'rith Women Delegates Assembly. Mail-in ballots are due by Oct. 15.

DOC.HEAD: Evangelist To Battle San Francisco's `Spirits Of Perversion'
DOC.TEXT: A Texas evangelist has ordered hundreds of thousands of ``prayer warriors'' to descend on San Francisco on Halloween to fight what he called the satanic forces of witchcraft, drugs and perversion. ``We need to reverse the curse on Halloween night,'' said Larry Lea, a televangelist who sometimes dons army fatigues and issues ``prayer army dog tags'' to followers. Lea said Friday that Halloween is innocent no more. ``This is not just kids having fun,'' he said. ``There is actual worship of the devil.'' Lea, whose daily ``Change Your Life'' television show is aired on 40 independent stations nationwide, is part of a growing movement of evangelical preachers who believe ``territorial spirits'' rule particular cities, industries and subcultures. According to Dick Bernal, pastor of the Jubilee Christian Center in San Jose, San Francisco is ruled by the Spirit of Perversion, Oakland by the spirit of murder, San Jose by the spirit of greed and Marin County, north of San Francisco, by the New Age spirit. These evil spirits can be exorcised through ``militant power-praying'' _ such as shouting, stomping, brandishing imaginary swords and speaking in tongues, Bernal and Lea explained. Lea, former pastor of the Church of the Rock in Rockwall, Texas, oversees 70 pastors and 40,000 churchmembers from his Dallas-based ministry. Last year, 6,000 people attended his three-day ``Prayer Breakthrough'' in Anaheim designed to ``inflict serious damage'' on evil spirits in Southern California. Lea said he would promote the San Francisco campaign on his television program. He said he has signed up 280,000 prayer warriors and wants at least 20,000 more. Some followers will go to the area's tallest buildings to pray over the city, he said. ``This area has been the launching pad for a lot of things we consider unbiblical _ free sex, the homosexual movement, acid rock,'' said Bernal, whose Jubilee Christian Center has 5,500 members. ``There are strong spirits of perversion and greed.'' Bernal's church holds annual conferences during which members pray at abortion clinics, New Age spirituality centers and newspaper offices to repel ``demonic forces.'' Many Pentecostal Christians and other conservative evangelicals believe that spirits control cities or buildings, said C. Peter Wagner, a professor of church growth at Fuller Theological Seminary in Pasadena. Professor Ron Enroth, a Christian sociologist at Westmont College in Santa Barbara, accused Lea of putting on a ``supernatural sideshow'' and ``coming on like God's Green Beret and whipping people up in a militaristic manner.'' ``Rather than facing up to the structural problems of our society, they find a demon behind every problem,'' he said. ``They are looking for quick fixes by pushing God's buttons.''

DOC.HEAD: Turnout Relatively Low For Resort Hit By Riot Last Year
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Hotels were...' to UPDATE with hotels now 75 percent full; SUBS 9th graf, `City officials ...' with 28,000 visitors in town
DOC.TEXT: City officials were confident they could prevent the violence that marred last year's Labor Day beach festival, but visitors said the heightened security this year was also dampening the fun. Fraternities and sororities from predominantly black schools along the East Coast have held an annual end-of-summer fest in Virginia Beach for the last 10 years. Last year's festivities were marred by looting and clashes between police and college-aged youths that resulted in 220 arrests, 43 injuries, $1.4 million in damage to stores and lingering accusations of police brutality. To prevent another outbreak, the city put its entire 600-member police force to work, and designed a parking plan to keep cars off the beach. By 5:30 p.m., 16 people had been arrested, 12 for public drunkenness, said Craig Andrews, media coordinator for Laborfest. Hotels were about three-quarters full by Saturday night, but merchants said they were doing little more business than a typical summer weekend. ``It's very much toned down this year, but probably a little bit too much,'' said Rodney Williams, a 21-year-old student from Farmingdale College in New York. ``I understand the need for the security measures, but this is kind of too much.'' After last year's violence, many black fraternity members claimed that white merchants and city officials had been harassing them. The city appointed a biracial committee to help plan this year's event. City officials, who estimated the 1989 crowd at more than 100,000, said the problems started because of too many people in too small an area with too little to do. At 5 p.m. Saturday, the crowd on the beachfront resort strip was estimated at 28,000, Andrews said. Virginia Beach Police Chaplain Don R. Staton said the atmosphere was relaxed this year because of fewer people. ``Places that were usually crowded, weren't,'' he said. Some of those who did make the trip were unhappy with what they found. ``There's too much police, said Ben Ogbogu, of Greenbelt, Md., who was making his third annual visit. ``I think that's going to cause people to get nervous and start some of the same thing that happened last year. It doesn't look peaceful. It looks militant.'' As part of preparations for the weekend, the city closed off a 200-block section of the beachfront to cars. Visitors were directed to satellite parking areas, with shuttle buses carrying them to and from the beach. Tanya Dance, 23, of Wilmington, Del., complained about the traffic restrictions. ``I'm paying $100 a night for a hotel room and I can't even go out in my car,'' she said. Saturday morning, the main beachfront thoroughfare was nearly empty as the afternoon began for what is usually the biggest vacation weekend of the year. ``You can see the tumbleweeds go down the street,'' said Deepak Nachnani, a shop manager. ``It's like a ghost town.'' Others said a holiday without violence would be worth a few lost dollars. ``I would like to think that we can measure this weekend in other than economic terms,'' said Flo McDaniel, executive director of the Virginia Beach Hotel and Motel Association. City officials would not give a number of visitors that would be necessary to call Laborfest a success. But Arthur Jarrett Jr., president of the student government association at Norfolk State University and a member of the committee that planned the event, said, ``Success for me is that our image is changed from the hellraisers we were depicted as last year. If I'm the only one at the beach, I want to have a good time.'' For Deborah Lee of New York City, who came ``for the action, the excitement and the men,'' there were still plenty of opportunities for ``enjoying the scenery.''

DOC.HEAD: Favorable Winds Pushing Sun Seeker Toward Kitty Hawk
DOC.TEXT: Favorable winds pushed the solar-powered Sun Seeker plane about 125 miles Saturday and put the craft as close as a day away from its cross-country destination of Kitty Hawk, N.C. Pilot Eric Raymond touched down at 6:15 p.m. at the Lunenburg County Airport near this tiny town about 60 miles southwest of Richmond, after about 6{ hours in the air, said spokesman Jack Whitehouse in Los Angeles. The plane landed about 150 miles away from Kitty Hawk, birthplace of powered flight and the scheduled end of Raymond's trip that began in California. With good weather, the plane could reach Kitty Hawk on Sunday, said Whitehouse. Raymond averaged 20 mph Saturday in the 198-pound plane. ``It was a good flight, good soaring weather,'' Whitehouse said. Raymond was pushed by northwest tail winds across a sky strewn with puffy clouds, Whitehouse said. The plane suffered a slight loss of power because of a decrease of voltage from its batteries, the spokesman said. The power loss was not life threatening for Raymond, 33, a former national hang gliding champion. Raymond's cross-country flight is intended to show the potential of solar power. The plane takes off under a solar-powered motor turning the propeller, then flies like a glider. Sun Seeker first took off on July 16 from Desert Center, Calif. Two days later, the craft was seriously damaged in an aborted takeoff from Lordsburg, N.M. The craft, pilot and crew returned to Lake Elsinore, Calif. for repairs. It took off again from Desert Center Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Stealth Fighters Use Temple For Target Practice
DOC.TEXT: A Mormon Church temple is a favorite mock target of military pilots training in stealth fighter-bombers, a Utah congressman said. Rep. Jim Hansen, a Republican, said a squadron of the futuristic F-117A fighter-bombers use the illuminated, spired temple in St. George as a target on their mock bombing runs. The church in St. George, 250 miles south of Salt Lake City, is one of the first Mormon temples built in Utah. ``They take out the St. George temple every night. I was out there watching them do it a few times,'' said Hansen, a member of the House Armed Services Committee. The F117-A was designed to penetrate radar defense and bomb targets before enemy forces can react, according to the Pentagon. The plane has been flying since 1981, but the Pentagon refused to even acknowledge it existed until late 1988. A squadron of the planes recently flew to Saudi Arabia for Operation Desert Shield. Hansen said the figher pilots, based at the Tonopah Test Range in Nevada, mean no disrespect to the 1.7 million-member Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, based in Salt Lake. ``The commander of the group was a (Mormon) bishop so I guess he felt all right taking out the St. George temple,'' said Hansen, who spoke Thursday to a group of Ogden-area businessmen about U.S. military technology.

DOC.TEXT: More than 100 Americans and several hundred other foreigners left Baghdad on jetliners for home Saturday, but many others remained behind, prompting President Bush to criticize Iraq for freeing the hostages too slowly. In another major development, Bush announced on Saturday that he and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will meet in Helsinki, Finland, on Sept. 9 to discuss the Middle East and other matters, including arms control. ``I'm glad when any American comes out of there, but there's a certain brutality, a certain tawdry performance in all of this,'' Bush said, when asked about Iraq's policy of releasing a few hundred captives at a time. ``It is so base and so outrageous that I think most people in the Arab world are very embarrassed by this, and I think that's certainly true of others around the world,'' Bush told reporters in Kennebunkport, Maine. The summit announcement indicates Moscow may be willing to play a larger role in resolving the crisis caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2. Progress also was reported on another diplomatic front Saturday. Sources in Amman, Jordan, where U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar and a senior Iraqi official met, said the two men were discussing a plan designed to prevent a war between Iraq and United States. The sources said the plan would create an Arab peacekeeping force to act as a buffer between the tens of thousands of Iraqi troops in occupied Kuwait and the U.S.-led multinational force being deployed in Saudi Arabia. The Soviet Union might help mediate simultaneous withdrawals of Iraqi troops from Kuwait and opposing forces from Saudi Arabia, the sources said. Perez de Cuellar and Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz expressed optimism, but neither would comment on the reports when their two-day meeting ended. ``The talks were very fruitful,'' Aziz said. ``This situation is complicated and dramatic (and) cannot be resolved by dramatic diplomacy. It needs patience. It needs time and people to understand exactly the positions.'' But at a press conference later, Perez de Cuellar said he was disappointed more progress had not been made. ``I had hoped for more,'' Perez de Cullar said, without elaborating. The United States, meanwhile, continued to pour troops and military hardware into Saudi Arabia, where a multinational force is being deployed to oppose Iraqi troops massed near Kuwait's border with Saudi Arabia. Until recently, American troops had remained well south of Saudi Arabia's border, but now they are moving north to bolster the force's defensive lines and significantly improve its offensive capabilities. U.S. officials say the movement northward of several units indicates that U.S. commanders in Saudi Arabia are now comfortable putting troops a good distance away from major supply points. ``If nothing else, it shows we believe we are now capable of sustaining a significant force in forward positions,'' a senior Air Force officer said. U.S. officials say more than 100,000 troops, including those aboard dozens of ships, are in the Persian Gulf region or on the way. The United States could contribute as many as 250,000 soldiers to the multinational force, which includes token contingents from other nations. For most of the day Saturday, the United States and other nations waited to see how many of the women and children among the 21,000 Westerners held hostage in Iraq and Kuwait would be allowed to leave for home. After lengthy delays, an Iraqi Airways plane with 68 Japanese women and children aboard was the first to leave Iraq for Jordan. It arrived in Amman, and the hostages were to land in Tokyo on Sunday. A Lufthansa plane took off next with 311 women and children from 22 countries, including about 60 Americans of Iraqi extraction and 71 Germans. The flight landed in Frankfurt early Sunday. A few arriving passengers smiled briefly or waved, but nearly all looked grim and exhausted. Some women carried sleeping children on their shoulders. One woman's eyes flooded with tears as she walked into the terminal. Diana Haroon, 24, an Iraqi-American from Chicago, said: ``Everybody wanted to go back to the United States because we have American citizenship and we can't stay there (in Baghdad) all the time. ... It's not good there.'' An Iraqi Airways 747 left Baghdad early Saturday bound for Paris, London and Washington. That flight carried 199 Britons, about 50 Americans and more than 20 French citizens, although there was confusion over the numbers. The plane arrived in London early Sunday after the Paris stopover, then left for Washington at 6:55 local time (1:55 EDT). The flight was expected to take 7{ hours, airport officials said. The British Foreign Office in London said departure of the Iraqi Airways jetliner from Baghdad had been delayed by the late arrival of a flight from Kuwait City carrying the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the American civil rights activist. Jackson flew to Kuwait early Saturday to collect sick Americans after meeting twice with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to secure their release. Jackson eventually brought 26 Americans out of Kuwait and another four who had come out of Kuwait by car joined his group in Baghdad. The State Department estimates that about 1,000 American women and children were stranded in Iraq and Kuwait by the invasion. Saddam announced last week that all foreign women and children could leave, but the process was delayed by red tape and new demands by Iraq. National security adviser Brent Scowcroft joined Bush on Saturday in criticizing Saddam for playing ``a game'' with the hostages in which ``the rules change daily, sometimes hourly.'' Scowcroft _ who also spoke with reporters in Kennebunkport _ demanded that Saddam free all foreign hostages, including the Western men who have been moved to Iraqi military installtions to deter a possible U.S. attack. In addition to deploying troops in Saudi Arabia, the United States and other nations also are enforcing a trade embargo against Iraq, and it appears the sanctions are beginning to cause hardships in Iraq. Iraq has issued coupon books to prepare for rationing that began Saturday, and sources in Baghdad said food distribution centers have been set up. The coupons entitle each Iraqi to a monthly allocation of 13 pounds of flour, 3.3 pounds of rice, 2.2 pounds of sugar, 3.5 ounces of tea, 1.1 pounds of oil, 17 ounces of detergent and one bar of soap, the sources said. Children under a year old receive three cans of powdered milk each month, but older children receive none. Elsewhere in the Middle East, the Persian Gulf crisis continued to open rifts in the Arab world and upset the balance of power in the region. After a two-day meeting in Egypt, the Arab League hardened its position on the invasion by demanding Iraq pay war reparations to Kuwait after withdrawing its troops. The League also demanded that Iraq immediately free all hostages. The crisis also reportedly has left Israel, Egypt and Saudi Arabia scrambling for more arms and financial assistance from the United States. Bush administration officials say the president has decided to make available more high-tech weapons for Israel and is considering forgiving Egypt's $6.7 billion military debt with the United States. Additional weapons for Israel would bolster that country's defense against Iraq and offset recent decisions to sell Saudi Arabia more tanks and warplanes.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds of Foreigners, Including Americans, Fly Out of Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th-12th pvs, `A third...in London' to UPDATE with plane leaving London, 199 Britons leaving plane; Pickup 13th, `One of...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of foreign women and children, including more than 100 Americans, flew to freedom Saturday aboard three jetliners from Baghdad. The first flight out of the Iraqi capital carried 68 Japanese women and children to Amman, Jordan, where they boarded a Japan Air Lines plane to Tokyo. Later, a Lufthansa plane took off from Baghdad with 250 women and 61 children on board, including 60 Americans and 71 Germans, the West German foreign ministry said. The Americans were of Iraqi origin. After a five-hour flight, the plane landed Sunday in Frankfurt. None of the passengers were sick or injured, the ministry said. Lufthansa said a preliminary list showed 316 people were on the flight, and at least one German man got off the plane. The Foreign Ministry said it did not have any information yet on men aboard the flight. A few arriving passengers smiled briefly or waved, but nearly all looked grim and exhausted. Some women carried sleeping children on their shoulders. One woman's eyes flooded with tears as she walked into the terminal. Diana Haroon, 24, an Iraqi-American from Chicago, said: ``Everybody wanted to go back to the United States because we have American citizenship and we can't stay there (in Baghdad) all the time. ... It's not good there.'' ``It's tough,'' she said, describing the situation in Iraq. Asked if she was nervous before she was allowed to leave, she said ``Sure.'' A third flight, an Iraqi Airways 747, landed in London after a stopover in Paris then left for Washington at 6:55 local time (1:55 EDT). The flight was expected to take 7{ hours, Heathrow airport officials said. The 747 was believed to have carried 199 Britons, about 50 Americans and more than 20 French nationals from Baghdad. The French Foreign Ministry, however, said the flight was carrying more than 340 evacuees from Iraq. Seventeen French women and five children disembarked from the plane after it landed at Orly International Airport south of Paris, and the 199 Britons left the flight in London. One of three American citizens who had requested permission to get off in Paris was also allowed to disembark so he could visit his seriously ill wife in Switzerland, said U.S. Embassy spokesman Parker Hallberg. There were varying reports on how many Americans were on the flight. Hallberg said there were about 40 Americans on the plane, but reports from Baghdad indicated about 50 U.S. citizens boarded there. The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who was aboard the flight, said there were 55 U.S. evacuees. ``There was no evidence of abusive treatment but there was great tension,'' Jackson told reporters in Paris. ``There was a sense of jubilation.'' A U.S. embassy doctor, Esther Roberts, was the only person allowed to board the plane during the stopover in Paris, embassy officials said. ``It's considered an Iraqi military mission,'' Hallberg said. He said Iraqi security officials were on board the plane, but he did not know whether they were armed. There was so much confusion over numbers at Baghdad airport that not even ambassadors had accurate totals of their own nationals on board. Some of the American and British women interviewed at Baghdad airport before departure said they left husbands behind as part of Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein's human shield at strategic installations to deter any U.S. attack. ``Our husbands are being held, and we don't want to put them in danger,'' said an American woman standing in line at Baghdad airport who declined to give her name. Another, Debby Willis of Parkman, Maine, said she and her husband, Jerry Willis, were trying to escape across the desert from Kuwait when Iraqi troops captured them. Her husband stayed behind at a military site, she said. Authorities held the Iraqi flight full of Americans and Britons until Jackson, the American civil rights activist, returned from Kuwait with sick American hostages whose release he gained after meeting twice with Saddam. Jackson brought 26 hostages out of Kuwait, including 20 people suffering from various illnesses. Only one of them required a stretcher _ a woman who broke her hip in a car accident while being moved from Kuwait to Baghdad. Four people who had come out of Kuwait by car were added to Jackson's party in Baghdad, bringing his total to 30. As many as 21 other Americans who had been detained in Iraq also boarded the flight. Jackson's departure from Kuwait was delayed by protracted negotiations to bring out an American woman who had called him at his hotel with a plea to take her out with him. Jackson was believed to have said he would not leave without her. At Baghdad's airport, Jackson told The Associated Press: ``This is a window of hope, and it must be expanded.'' He said he was encouraged by his meetings with Saddam, whom he found ready to talk. ``When people are willing to talk, that is a step in the first direction,'' Jackson said. ``There must be a cooling of the rhetoric in this quest for peace.'' He urged U.S. senators and congressmen to use their influence to expand the window of opportunity in Iraq, adding: ``Diplomacy must not take a backseat to economic resistance and military preparedness.'' In all, about 21,000 Westerners were trapped in Iraq and Kuwait by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of its oil-rich neighbor. They included 3,000 Americans.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Chief Says He's Disappointed After Talks With Aziz
DOC.TEXT: U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar indicated Sunday that his effort to avert a military showdown in the gulf has failed, saying he was disappointed by Iraq's inflexibility. ``As I leave, I must acknowledge a certain disappointment,'' the U.N. chief told a televised news conference after four meetings with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. ``The main problem was the occupation and annexation of Kuwait by Iraq,'' he said. Answering a reporter's question in French, the Secretary General said: ``The talks were useful, but disappointing ... I had hoped for a more flexible position regarding the retreat of the Iraqis from Kuwait.'' The U.N. chief said he was leaving for Paris to brief Jordan's King Hussein on the outcome of the talks. The Jordanian monarch, an ally of Iraq, has been trying to defuse tensions escalating since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Hussein is in Europe this weekend seeking to avert further escalation of the crisis as the U.S.-led multinational force continued to build in Saudi Arabia. Thousands of mostly U.S. troops face more than 200,000 Iraqi soldiers along Saudi Arabia's northern borders with Iraq and Kuwait. A Jordanian official who had been close to the talks between Aziz and the U.N. chief said Saturday the two men were close to a plan that would edge the Middle East back from the brink of war. It mainly called for setting up a buffer between the Iraqis and the multinational troops in Saudi Arabia to be manned by an Arab peacekeeping force. Under the plan, the Iraqis would free all foreign nationals still held in occupied Kuwait and Iraq. The final step would be a simultaneous withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait and the multinational forces in Saudi Arabia. But it appeared a last-minute hitch undermined the plan. Perez de Cuellar did not refer directly to the plan. But his repeated references to Iraq's ``inflexibility'' indicated he had failed to win a pledge from the Iraqis to relinquish Kuwait, or at least discuss that as an option. Perez de Cuellar said Aziz reiterated his country's position that the issue of Kuwait needed ``an Arab solution,'' away from foreign intervention. But the U.N. chief stressed to Aziz the crisis has taken on ``international dimensions'' and that the ``global interests and principles have to be acknowledged.'' Perez de Cuellar said he welcomed Iraq's decision to free hundreds of foreign women and children, but that he told Aziz this was not enough. He said, ``I emphasized that this decision should be followed by another ... that all restrictions on foreigners and their movement be lifted. Hundreds of foreign women and children as well as some sick Americans flew to freedom Saturday. They were the first of the hostages flown out of Iraq since Baghdad last week said they would be allowed to leave. But thousands more foreigners, mostly men, are still banned from leaving Iraq, many of them interned at key installations to avert a potential U.S. attack. When Iraq invaded Kuwait, about 21,000 Westerners, including 3,000 Americans, were caught in both countries.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Troops End Blockade of Road
DOC.TEXT: The Canadian Army took control Sunday of the highway running through the Mohawk territory of Kahnesatake, ending the blockade of the road that began 54 days ago. On Sunday morning, about two dozen troops backed by two armored personnel carriers moved onto the highway and began approaching the main barricade at the top of the Oka hill, 18 miles west of Montreal, where defiant Mohawks have waged an armed standoff with government authorities. When the army moved in Sunday morning, none of the Mohawks made a move to stop the troops. The soldiers strung barbed wire around the main barricade on highway 344 and began to inspect it for mines and booby traps. An army helicopter, with guns pointed out its side doors, flew low overhead. ``Thank God it's over,'' said Master Cpl. Daniel Dugas as he stood on the highway. ``It's about time and I'm happy it happened without a shot.'' Gen. Armand Roy, commander of the Canadian Forces 5th Brigade, said he decided to send in his troops after two Mohawk men were wounded in factional fighting behind Indian barricades set up in a land dispute with government officials. ``I decided to move my troops so as to guarantee the security of civilians and my soldiers,'' Roy said. The military action came after efforts failed to reach a negotiated settlement in the dispute. The Mohawks have been trying to block a golf course extension on land they claim is theirs, but they have also raised other grievances. On Saturday, defiant Indian militants stood their ground and screamed at Canadian soldiers to get away as troops pushed to within 100 yards of the main barricade Saturday afternoon. The troops moved into an area where the army had estimated at least 50 armed members of the militant Mohawk Warrior's Society were located. Provincial authorities Monday had given the military the go-ahead to end the armed standoff that began July 11, when the Quebec provincial police attempted to storm a Mohawk barricade at Oka. One officer was killed, but it is still not clear by whose gunfire. Later that day, fellow Mohawks set up a blockade in sympathy at the Mercier bridge, a major link between Montreal and its southern suburbs. The ostensible reason for the Mohawk uprising _ expansion of the golf course _ was settled when the federal government purchased the land and said it would turn it over to the Indians. But militants seized the situation to publicize a much wider range of Indian grievances against the government, including demands for sovereignty. On Friday, Mohawks from the Kanewake reserve south of Montreal allowed troops to remove the main barricades they had set up on routes leading to the Mercier bridge. Quebec Transport Department officials said it would take several days before the bridge can be reopened to traffic. The bridge blockade forced thousands of commuters on the south shore of the St. Lawrence River to make long detours to Montreal, which is on an island. Angry residents have protested and thrown rocks at Mohawks.
