DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi jetliner bearing two dozen American women and children landed at Dulles International Airport today, one month after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait turned foreigners in both countries into captives. The flight landed at 9:38 a.m. EDT. The passengers, weary from more than 24 hours of waiting and traveling, were greeted by family members and U.S. officials. Ex-hostage Lloyd Culbertson, 76, of El Paso, Texas, said the hostages left behind were being held without food and water. ``If it were not for the grace of God and Jesse Jackson, we would not be here. The State Department has not lifted a hand for us,'' Culbertson said. One of the arriving passengers, a woman, was put on an ambulance and taken to a local hospital. ``It is not a serious illness,'' said Barbara Cebuhar, a spokeswoman for the Family Support Administration of the Department of Health and Human Resources, which is charged with helping the Americans. A State Department official said Jackson, who helped arrange the flight to freedom, put the number of Americans on board at 24. Jackson, at a stopover in Paris, had said there were 55 Americans on the plane. Iraq's ambassador to the United States, Mohamed Mashat, was among those awaiting the flight's arrival. Mike Brennan, a State Department spokesman, said Mashat told U.S. officials he was there to assure that the crew had no problems. Jackson, traveling as a television journalist, had met twice last week with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. He told reporters, ``Now that the military has played its role, diplomacy must work. If preconditions make talks impossible, war is inevitable.'' The Iraqi Airways 747 was one of three jetliners to leave Baghdad Airport on Saturday. The flights carried hundreds of foreign women and children, who left their husbands and fathers behind, and ailing men. About 21,000 Westerners were trapped in Iraq and Kuwait by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of its oil-rich neighbor. They included 3,000 Americans. Saddam had announced last Tuesday he would allow the departure of women and children, who had previously been held. More than a week earlier, however, Saddam had ordered troops and officials to round up Western men to be used as human shields around military installations and other strategic locations. The flight to Dulles was the only of the three with the United States as its final destination. A Lufthansa jet landed in Frankfurt, West Germany, with 60 Iraqi-Americans among its passengers. The other flight took 68 Japanese women and children out of the country. Immediately after the jumbo jet landed at a remote terminal of the airport, officials began taking the arriving passengers through customs and other formalities as quickly as possible. Cebuhar said that the returning hostages could go to a hotel or travel directly home.

DOC.HEAD: Extra Fire Watch at Robin Hood's Hideout
DOC.TEXT: Sherwood Forest rangers have intensified their fire watch at the Major Oak, the tree where legend says Robin Hood and his merry men hid out. Authorities say drought has turned parts of the forest tinder-dry, and fire patrols have been stepped up, especially at the 60-foot tall Major Oak. The tree, thought to be 600 to 800 years old, is a favorite tourist attraction at Sherwood Forest.

DOC.HEAD: Storm Leaves 20 Missing, Destroys Many Homes in Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: At least 20 fishermen were missing and homes were destroyed as Tropical Storm Becky lashed northern Vietnamese provinces, the official Vietnam News Agency said. Becky hit Nghe Tinh last Wednesday with heavy rains winds of more than 70 mph, the agency said Saturday. A text was seen in Bangkok Sunday. The agency said the storm destroyed about 395,200 acres of rice paddy and severely damaged many thatched-roof homes. ``Many portions of roads and dikes were washed away and three boats with 20 fishermen aboard were reported missing,'' it said. Becky struck the Philippines with typhoon-force winds last week, killing 32 people and forcing the evacuation of thousands of others from flooded areas. A typhoon has sustained winds of at least 74 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Tattooed Youths Banned From Joining Army
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of army recruits have been rejected for military service because of their tattoos, a newspaper reported Sunday. The Guangming Daily said tattoos were discovered on about 75 percent of the youths at a recent military recruitment campaign in Chengde, a city northeast of Beijing. It said most of the 574 tattooed youths used cigarettes or sticks to make various designs, which the paper did not describe. It also did not say why the army objects to tattoos. About 5 percent had tattoos of Chinese characters for ``fortune,'' ``longevity,'' ``strength,'' ``revenge'' and ``unity'' which their parents had given them as children in hopes of bringing good luck to the family, the paper said. By March, about 5,100 young people from rural Beijing had joined the army, an earlier report said. But no nationwide figures were available.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Warfare Training Takes on Edge of Reality
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
Laserphoto XSAV1
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The 265th Quartermaster Detachment of the South Carolina National Guard is one of the reserve units called up for possible duty in Saudi Arabia. National Writer Fred Bayles is following this small unit of 14 guardsmen as they prepare for deployment overseas.

When nine seconds were up, at least five men of the 265th Quartermaster Detachment were dead, a fact that did not please some of the casualties. ``I was not dead,'' said a petulant Sgt. Ronnie Jackson, leader of 14-member National Guard unit preparing for deployment to the Mideast. But the sergeant instructing the unit in NBC _ nuclear, biological, chemical warfare _ explained patiently that Jackson's gas mask straps were still tangled nine seconds after she shouted go. If this had been a nerve gas attack, he still wouldn't be struggling to get the mask on, or have any breath left to argue. Ernie Deloach, the stocky corrections guard who is another of the unit's sergeants, took the side of the instructor. ``If you start twitching, I'll have to shoot you and take command,'' he told Jackson. Muffled laughter came from the circle of hooded guardsmen standing in the light Georgia rain. Thunder from the storm boomed in the distance. Chemical warfare exercises are not new to the 265th, a water purification unit activated for duty in the Persian Gulf. Many of the men have two decades in the South Carolina National Guard. They trained yearly with gas masks and bulky chemical suits. But never before has this practice had such a sharp edge of reality. The men are likely to go to a place where chemical warfare is no drill. ``No one took this stuff seriously before now. Now everyone is scared,'' said Sgt. Iris Craig, the unit's instructor. The sergeant is an intense teacher who rewards students with a withering stare when they give an out-of-the-ballpark answer to her questions. ``You need to wake up people,'' she said at one slow point in class. ``If you could not effectively identify a chemical agent, you could become a casualty.'' But there is a lot to remember, or ``compute,'' as Craig keeps saying. It's hard to keep it all straight. There's VX, GA, GB, GD, blood agents, blister agents, persistent and non-persistent gases. Is it GA that has a fruity odor and AC that smells like bitter almonds? Or is it the other way around? It is a challenge, with your head pounding inside the gas mask, to follow the 14 steps on your index-card-size M256 Detector Kit and chose between the pastel blues and purples of the color chart to see if you've been exposed to mustard or phosgene. ``There's no way we're going to remember it all,'' said Spc. Willie Badger, a 34-year-old electrician. ``I'm just trying to remember the important stuff.'' A member of the 265th for nine years, Badger is affectionately known as Bonehead to other unit members, after his shining pate. Badger shaves his head each time he goes off on National Guard deployment. His friends also tease him about his snoring, wondering out loud if his wife finally is getting a good night's sleep now that he has been called up. ``We mess around a lot, but when it comes to doing the job, we're all business,'' he said. Badger spends his time in line outside the mess hall reading his pocket Bible. He comes from a devout family; his mother wanted him to be a preacher. But Badger confesses he is considered the backslider of the family because he drinks and smokes. Don't worry, calls one his buddies, alcohol isn't allowed in Saudi Arabia. ``My mom said she hopes when I come back I'll try preaching, but I don't think so,'' he said with a grin.

DOC.HEAD: Gandhi Top In Opinion Poll
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh trails former premier Rajiv Gandhi as the favorite man for the nation's top post, according to an opinion poll published Sunday. Singh, who ousted Gandhi in elections last year, was preferred by 36 percent of the respondents, compared with 44 percent who favored Gandhi for prime minister. Twenty percent said both men were equal. The poll by Marketing and Research Group found 29 percent of the 10,239 registered voters questioned thought Singh was doing a good job, and an equal number thought he was doing badly. He was given a middle rating by 42 percent. Thirty-eight percent thought Gandhi was deoing a good job, the poll reported. Gandhi became prime minister after the 1984 assassination of his mother, Indira Gandhi. The poll was published in the biweekly India Today magazine. No margin of error was given.

DOC.HEAD: Plague Kills Three
DOC.TEXT: An outbreak of the bubonic plague has killed three people in a low-income neighborhood on Nairobi's eastern outskirts and 23 others have become ill, newspapers reported Sunday. The three killed worked at a flour mill which has closed temporarily as a precaution against further spread of the disease, according to Kenya's three English-language dailies. The disease, also known as the Black Death, is transmitted to humans by fleas from infected rats and is treatable with antibiotics. Epidemics of the plague have occured throughout history, with the best known being the Black Death that swept Europe and parts of Asia in the 14th century, killing millions of people. As a result of the disease's outbreak in Embakasi, a low-income area on Nairobi's eastern outskirts, leave for city health officials has been canceled, the Sunday Standard reported. The government also has issued a list of preventive measure to help stem the disease's spread, such as putting out chemicals to kill rats and spraying insecticides in vehicles and baggage to kill fleas.

DOC.HEAD: Some Press for a Quick Strike, But Military Says It's Not Ready
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is getting conflicting advice on whether he should _ or even could _ strike against Iraq fast, before the extraordinary coalition of nations that confronts Saddam Hussein unravels. But the military is cautioning against it. Pentagon officials say privately that the American buildup in Saudi Arabia is weeks away from being ready for warfare, especially ground combat. ``Absolutely not,'' a military source said when asked last week about the possibility of an offensive operation. ``We're just not ready yet. We don't have enough force on the ground.'' Administration officials say there is some pressure from within Congress and from abroad to attack even without a provocative act from Saddam, whose forces have pulled back from the ``cat-and-mouse'' air and sea taunts of a few days ago. One official, speaking on condition of anonymity, conceded that if too much time passes the coalition against Saddam, particularly in the Arab world, ``could fragment.'' At home, he acknowledged, public support might drain away in the face of a stalemate. For the time being, Bush seems willing to wait to see if he can strangle Saddam into submission through a worldwide blockade of Iraq. ``The basic pieces of our policy are in place,'' he told a news conference Thursday. So officials say it is unlikely he will launch an unprovoked attack. The White House believes Saddam is on the run, one official said. White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk characterized as ``uninformed speculation'' reports of pressure on the administration for a military move. ``We have a strategy in place based on the United Nations resolution and the U.N.-passed sanctions,'' he said. One official cited intelligence reports that Saddam is ``trying to use oil as a bargaining chip'' to underscore the administration portrait of the Iraqi president as an increasingly desperate man. He said Saddam was trying to barter oil for sugar and other commodities. Such overtures have been made to Turkey, the Philippines and elsewhere, he said. Also arguing against a quick-strike strategy _ one powerful enough presumably to remove Iraq as a threat to Western interests for years to come _ is the situation on the ground. U.S. forces are just beginning to assume defensive positions and need more training in the hostile desert environment. Thousands more troops are on the way to bolster the more than 60,000 U.S. military personnel already in the gulf region. Allied Arab forces are even less combat ready and the Saudi troops that constitute a border trip-wire defense are poorly prepared to cope with gas warfare _ or an onslaught of powerful Iraqi tanks. On Friday, Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the commander of U.S. forces in the Middle East, said flatly: ``There's not going to be any war unless the Iraqis attack.'' If Saddam Hussein launched an attack, ``We'd respond, because we'd have to,'' Schwarzkopf said. ``But we just don't have enough armor on the ground yet to launch any kind of offensive.'' A U.S.-initiated attack would change the political configuration and upset the anti-Saddam alliance Bush has pieced together, analysts caution. The Arab world could easily become united behind Saddam and against the United States if Bush is seen as having used Iraq's takeover of Kuwait as an excuse to establish a permanent American presence in the Mideast. The Soviet Union would be uneasy about a major U.S. military advance in the Middle East _ a subject Bush is likely to discuss with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev on Sunday in Helsinki, Finland. As it is, the leaders of Jordan and Egypt must worry about Saddam's popularity among the masses. Saddam has tried to capitalize on public discontent in the poorer Arab countries by picturing Israel as the hidden villain in the gulf crisis and denouncing Saudi Arabia's royal rulers for allowing ``infidel'' Americans to despoil the site of Islam's holiest places. But American military officials in Saudi Arabia, who spoke on grounds they wouldn't be quoted by name, said that if the United States were intent on striking first it could have used its air power to punish the Iraqi army in the first days of the invasion, before Saddam had time to amass a huge force near the Saudi border. Some Saudi officials say that if fighting breaks out it will be because Saddam initiates it _ or is goaded into taking a provocative act. And at the Pentagon, a senior official contended there's no first-strike sentiment in the top military ranks. ``They do the planning,'' he said of the military chiefs. ``They know what's required. But contrary to popular belief, they are not the ones who are pushing for going into combat. They know what war involves and they know its costs. I call it a `war-wariness' on their part.''

DOC.HEAD: Robert E. Lee Thank-You Note On Sale
DOC.TEXT: A letter of thanks for the gift of a uniform and blankets, said to have been written by General Robert E. Lee, is on auction. The letter is dated April 22, 1864, a year before the American Civil War ended with Lee's surrender at Appomattox. It was sent from the confederate leader's headquarters to a Major L.B. Ferguson in England, who apparently was a regular supporter of the general. ``I have often wished to thank you for the kind sentiment and high appreciation of the army of North Virginia,'' the letter says. It acknowledges ``the uniforms and blankets you so kindly sent me,'' and adds: ``I beg you will not add to your troubles by administering to my comfort. We have, partly owing to your efforts and partly to the exertions of our people, everything we actually want. All else we can dispense with.'' Auctioneer Michael Shortall said Sunday: ``The style of the prose is very much the style of an 18th-century English gentleman _ a nice little vignette of Lee at the end of his career.'' He said he was studying British army records to establish who Maj. L.B. Ferguson was. The letter is among the contents of Heronden Hall in Kent County which are being auctioned on Sept. 10.

DOC.HEAD: British Boy Shown With Saddam Goes Home
DOC.TEXT: Stuart Lockwood, the 5-year-old British boy seen worldwide on TV next to Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein, is home and recovering. But there will be no celebrations until his father gets back, his aunt said Sunday. ``He is only 5 years old and I do not think he really knows what has been happening. It has been like an adventure for him,'' said Stuart's aunt, Judy Campbell. ``Stuart's dad is still in Iraq. There will be no family celebration until he is home. We hope that his return will be soon,'' she said at her home in Worcester, western England. ``Everyone is fit and well,'' she added. Stuart flew home Saturday with his mother, Glenda, and 14-year-old brother Craig along with more than 300 foreigners who had been held in Kuwait and Iraq. Iraq has detained about 21,000 foreigners, including 3,000 Americans, since it invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. His father Derek, 42, remained among those still held by Saddam. The family has lived in Kuwait for three years. Stuart became famous in an Iraqi TV film of Saddam sitting among British hostages. He was the solemn-faced child who was beckoned by Saddam and stood at the Iraqi leader's side having his hair fondled. The film, seen on TV networks the world over, was widely condemned as a propaganda stunt. Later, Iraqi TV aired more footage of Stuart playing soccer and chess with four other hostage children.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Calls For Christian, Moslem Brotherhood
LaserPhoto PAR7
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Sunday urged cooperation and brotherhood between Christianity and Islam, two religions with ancient rivalries in Africa. ``Religious differences of themselves do not necessarily disrupt life together,'' the pope told leaders of the Moslem and other faiths in this East African nation. John Paul said dialogue between Christians and Moslems ``is increasingly important in today's world.'' ``Christians and Moslems can live in harmony and show their solidarity with one another in all the joys, sorrows and challenges'' of life, the pope said. ``Christians and Moslems in Tanzania can be partners in building a society shaped by the values taught by God: tolerance, justice, peace and concern for the poorest and weakest.'' Roman Catholicism and Islam, the world's two largest religions, have occasionally clashed in competition for converts in Africa. The Vatican has expressed concern about the spread of Moslem fundamentalism in parts of the continent. In an earlier speech to Catholic bishops Sunday, John Paul referred to those problems when he said the clergy needed to involve the laity more deeply in the church to avoid ``the proselytizing pressures from other faiths or religious groups.'' The Vatican has also suggested that the Moslem faith is not interested in dialogue and cooperation. But the pope hailed good relations between the two faiths in Tanzania, a largely Moslem country where Catholics make up only 21 percent of the population of 75 million. Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro said the Moslem community contributed financially to the papal visit. The nation's Moslem president, Ali Hassan Mwinyi, and a number of other prominent members of the faith attended the pope's open-air Mass earlier Sunday. Noting that ``both religions are deeply committed to the spread of their respective faiths,'' the pope said they nonetheless could build a firm foundation of collaboration and mutual respect. That foundation, he said, should be ``recognition that every person has an inalienable right and a solemn duty to follow his or her upright conscience.'' ``The Lord of heaven and earth cannot be pleased with a religious observance that is somehow imposed from without,'' John Paul said. ``What would then become of the wonderful gifts of reason and free will?'' The pope celebrated Mass in a huge outdoor arena built primarily for political functions on the outskirts of Dar Es Salaam. Up to 100,000 people gathered for the ceremony, at which the pope ordained 43 priests. In his homily, he urged the new priests to maintain their vows of celebacy, a major challenge for the church, particularly in Africa, where native tradition places great stress on fatherhood. The pope spoke in English but laced his homily with phrases of Swahili, the lingua franca of East Africa. drawing cheers and ululation from the crowd. A clapping, swaying, drum-beating women's choir, dressed in wraparound skirts and T-shirts bearing the pope's likeness, provided hours of rythmic, native hymns in Swahili. Sunday was the second day of the pope's seventh visit to Africa, a 10-day trip that will take him next to three other Tanzanian cities, then to Burundi, Rwanda and the west coast nation of Ivory Coast. He ends the trip there Sept. 10 with a consecration of a massive basilica.

DOC.HEAD: Man Slashes U.S. Artist's Paintings
DOC.TEXT: A man brandishing a knife slashed three paintings by U.S. artist Jeff Koons on display at an art show Sunday, an official said. The man escaped after spraying a chemical substance at seven guards who tried to apprehend him, causing their eyes to tear up, said Giovanni Carandente, director of the Biennale festival's art section, in a telephone interview. The vandal slashed three paintings depicting Koons with Italian porn star and parliamentarian Ilona Staller, known popularly as ``Cicciolina.'' The works were destroyed, Carandente said. Authorities did not know the motive for the man's act. The value of the paintings was not immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: For All Its Fears, Israel Finds Some Good In The Gulf Crisis
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: For all the fears and dangers it has raised, the Persian Gulf crisis has produced a shift in views of the Middle East that is welcome to Israel's right-wing government. Until Iraqi troops swept into Kuwait on Aug. 2, the world tended to ignore Israel's persistent warnings that President Saddam Hussein's thirst for power was a serious danger to the whole world, not just to Israel. The outside world seemed to focus on the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation and the efforts of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's government to put it down with bullets and beatings. Young stone-throwers were dying daily. PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat talked of compromise and Israel refused to talk to Palestinians. All that changed with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Defense Minister Moshe Arens expressed the satisfaction of the government when he said shortly after the invasion: ``I don't want to say I told you so, but I told you so.'' Saddam's invasion and annexation of Kuwait shifted attention from the Palestinian problem toward the broader question of Israeli-Arab relations. Yossi Olmert, director of the Government Press Office and a member of Shamir's conservative Likud bloc, says Iraq's military sweep proved that Saddam and not the Palestinian-Israeli conflict posed a danger to world order. ``The Palestinian uprising did not set off a global crisis, it was an Israeli crisis,'' Olmert told The Associated Press. ``Iraq-Kuwait is a global crisis.'' Iraq's invasion and the strong Western reaction also have produced several other changes pleasing to Israel: _Angry statements from the United States about Israeli foot-dragging on the Middle East peace process have been replaced by public thanks for Israel's ``restraint'' in the crisis. _It is now Arafat and Palestinians who face world criticism for their praise and support of Saddam as a strong Arab leader. _Concern by both Arabs and European governments that a flood of Soviet Jewish immigrants could move into the occupied territories has been suspended. The influx reached a monthly record of 16,000 in August. Despite those changes, there are nagging fears that the gulf crisis could produce terrible results for the Jewish state. In Israel, there is worry that Iraq could make good on its threat to attack with chemical weapons. And there is a possibility that even a political settlement could be bad for the Jewish state unless Saddam is swept from power. Arens told Israel television last week, ``If he stays at his post and would still possess the weapons, there will be a place for worry in our country, in the whole region and, I think, the whole world.'' Despite the rush of events, some Israelis also point out that the issue of 1.7 million Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip is not simply going to go away. ``It is best that extremists in the nationalist camp . . . do not rejoice yet,'' cautioned an editorial in the Hebrew daily Haaretz. ``The new relations being woven between the United States and some Arab nations will soon be felt.'' Political analysts in and out of the government believe that Egypt, Syria and other Arab nations supporting U.S. efforts against Saddam may unite behind the Palestinian cause when the gulf crisis is resolved. Fears have been raised that a successful U.S. campaign to end Iraq's occupation of Kuwait will raise troublesome questions about Israel's 23-year occupation of the West Bank and Gaza. Already, 728 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians since the revolt began in December 1987. An additional 254 Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most as suspected collaborators. Forty-seven Israelis also have been killed. Even the right-wing government knows it cannot simply forget the Palestinian question. Still, worries about the long-term impact of the gulf crisis cannot suppress the upbeat mood among officials and many in the Israeli public. For once, if only for the moment, Israelis seem to have reached some sort of political consensus in the face of Iraq's invasion. Even Yossi Sarid, a leader of the left-wing Citizens Rights Movement that has advocated talking to the PLO and giving up occupied land, wrote a column questioning his party's past stance. ``You need to put on a gas mask to protect yourself against the poisonous smell of the pro-Saddam stand of the Palestine Liberation Organization,'' Sarid said.
EDITOR'S NOTE: G.G. LaBelle is news editor of The Associated Press bureau in Jerusalem.

DOC.HEAD: Coping with the Gulf Crisis: Ex-Iran Hostages Remember the Waiting Game
DOC.TEXT: American families wait, fretful and helpless, while loved ones are held captive by a Middle East leader. To Dorothea Morefield, their emotions are chillingly familiar. ``More than anything else, there is a feeling of your life being out of control,'' she said, recalling her husband's captivity in Iran a decade ago. ``Someone that you love is in danger and there is nothing you can do.'' Today, the frustration belongs to relatives of the more than 2,000 U.S. citizens trapped since Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's troops invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. It's a waiting game familiar to the families of Americans seized in Tehran on Nov. 4, 1979, by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's revolutionaries. Fifty-two hostages endured 444 days in captivity. When the Iranian hostages finally came home to parades and cheering throngs, they called their families the true heroes. Their loved ones had been brave, resourceful and resolute. Most of all, they had carried on. ``Knowing that my family was strong, not having to worry about how they were going to cope, I could be concerned about hanging on myself,'' said Richard Morefield, former consul-general in Tehran. In Tehran, the hostages were the issue. In Iraq and Kuwait, they are the scattered byproduct of Saddam's invasion. Iran did not face an international military response and economic blockade. In 1979, the embassy hostages were diplomats and servicemen. Today's captives are mostly civilians. But if the scenarios differ, the coping is the same. Mrs. Morefield couldn't free her husband, but she could still carry on for him. So as the days turned into weeks, she gathered her five children and together they substituted pragmatism for panic. They drew up lists of State Department and other contacts, canceled credit cards and closed joint bank accounts. After tying up those loose ends, family members concentrated on keeping their hands busy and their minds occupied. Mrs. Morefield scrubbed floors, knitted afghans and took walks. Her children continued with their studies, sports and other hobbies. ``It's very important that you get on with your life, that you don't stagnate,'' said Mrs. Morefield, who now lives with her husband in Annandale, Va. ``You keep control of your life as much as you can.'' It's hard for relatives to avoid wild imaginings, the veterans of the Iran ordeal said. ``The hostages know their living conditions. They know how they're being treated and if they're being fed,'' said Kevin Hermening, who was a Marine guard in Tehran when the embassy was seized. ``Their families do not.'' His mother was criticized for visiting the hostages during their captivity, but Hermening understands her desperation. ``It's hardest on the families of hostages ... because they have only speculation,'' said Hermening, a new father and candidate for the Wisconsin Legislature. ``They don't know what their loved ones are going through.'' As the Persian Gulf crisis enters its second month, the families of those trapped overseas are in much the same situation. In many cases they can only guess the whereabouts of relatives, many of whom have been out of contact for weeks. ``When you're out there you know where the walls are,'' said former hostage Bruce Laingen, who was charge d'affaires and the top U.S. diplomat in Iran. ``When you're back here, you're constantly dealing with not knowing enough,'' said Laingen, now executive director of the National Commission on the Public Service. ``You're never happy, never satisfied. I'm sure that's true among many of the families today.'' But former hostages and their families warned against letting the frustration run rampant. Dignity is the thing, they said. ``Too much wringing of hands is not good for the national morale,'' said Moorhead Kennedy, who was the third-ranking foreign service officer at the U.S. Embassy in Tehran. ``Stand up! Remember who you are!'' His wife, Louisa, did just that. In the darkest days of the Iran hostage crisis, she went to work on a network for the victims' families. ``We considered ourselves hostages,'' said Mrs. Kennedy, who was spokeswoman for the Family Liaison Action Group in Washington. ``In my case, I resolved that in some degree by putting myself to work.'' ``It's very important for families to see this in context, see that it isn't some wicked thing that's just happening to them,'' added Kennedy, who works at the American Forum for Global Education in New York. Hostage families have to step back, try to see the bigger picture, said those who have been through it and survived. ``It's important for the family to remember that their relatives will be well,'' said former diplomat Barry Rosen, who is now an assistant vice president at Brooklyn College in New York. ``There's nothing like freedom, like being able to open the door and walk outside,'' he said. ``That cures a lot of ills.'' And families should never abandon hope, former hostages said. The door to freedom could soon swing open. ``You never know what the next day will bring,'' Rosen said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Cashiers Picket Stores They Say Falsely Accused Them of Stealing
DOC.TEXT: Former convenience store cashiers who say they were coerced into falsely confessing to thefts and repaying money they never stole are taking their battle from the courtroom to the sidewalks. ``Just sitting around talking about what happened only makes you madder,'' said Kenneth Provost of Chicopee, who with other former employees launched a picket Saturday of two Cumberland Farms stores in the chain's home state of Massachusetts. They are not alone in their anger. Despite the company's repeated denials of any wrongdoing, more than 300 former workers have approached lawyers handling a federal lawsuit against the company, saying they also were forced to sign false confessions. The suit, originally filed by 12 employees four years ago, is scheduled to go to trial in Camden, N.J., in December. Within the past few weeks, former workers in at least three states have created support groups. And the prosecutor's office in Orlando, Fla., says it will no longer routinely process theft claims filed by the company against workers. Many of those that have come forward said they paid hundreds and sometimes thousands of dollars to the company to avoid prosecution and the humiliation of a public accusation of theft. ``The reaction has been unbelievable,'' Provost said. ``Every day more people come in and say it happened to me too.'' In July, the Philadelphia Inquirer reported that during the first six months of 1986, Cumberland Farms security officials obtained confessions from 57 percent of the 2,600 cashiers they questioned about theft and collected $368,000 from the workers. And Frederic J. Gross, the attorney handling the federal suit, claims that over the past 20 years as many as 30,000 people who worked for the chain may have been accused of stealing. The estimate was based on internal ``report cards'' maintained by the company on the security staff, some of which have been obtained by the lawyers, Gross said. Foster G. MacRides, a vice president and chief spokesman for Cumberland Farms, did not return telephone messages left at the company's headquarters in the Boston suburb of Canton. But he has said repeatedly that the 50-year-old chain, which operates 1,100 stores in New England, New York, Pennsylvania, Delaware, New Jersey, Florida and Ohio, has ``never and will never have a policy of coercing or intimidating our employees.'' One woman, who had signed a ``confession'' as a teen-ager, told lawyers that for 15 years her father refused to believe her claims of innocence. But now she was stepping forward at his urging. Others said they had signed confessions as teen-agers in hopes of keeping the accusation from their parents, or were simply scared into signing. ``I was sobbing and crying so hard when they threatened to put me in jail and take away my children that I threw up,'' said Margaret Stone of Bennington, Vt., a divorced mother of six who was working at a New Hampshire store last year when she was accused of stealing $6,000. She said store officials told her if she signed a false confession and came up with $1,500 in cash by noon the next day, they would not have her jailed and her children would not be taken away. ``They even brought me out to the pay phone in the parking lot at 11:30 at night and made me call my parents for the money,'' she said. ``It was so cold and I was crying so hard that the security man took the phone from me and talked to my mother.'' ``It was the worst nightmare of my life.'' ``There are all these little tragedies out there and it's so damn unnecessary,'' said K. Kay Shearin, a Delaware lawyer. Shirley DiSalvo, one of Ms. Shearin's clients, was arrested by Delaware State Police and jailed for four days last month, even though she was nine months pregnant, after a computer check uncovered a 4-year-old warrant dating back to her brief stint as a clerk in a Florida store. Cumberland Farms accused her of stealing $2,900 after the woman, then 18, told store officials she had taken an unauthorized soft drink on a half dozen occasions when she worked overtime, according to Ms. Shearin. Provost said his support group recently began picketing because ``we wanted to do something to get the attention of other people that were victimized and thought they were alone.'' But sometimes just talking to someone who has been in the same straits helps, said Grettel Dunn, who started a support group in Rhode Island. ``I thought I was the only one it had ever happened to and I was so ashamed,'' said Mrs. Dunn. ``I never took anything in my life.'' Mrs. Dunn said she refused to sign a confession when she was called into the back room, sat down on a milk carton and told she could not leave. But she said she was in tears when she finally plucked up the courage to walk out amid shouted warnings that police would be waiting at her door. ``Needless to say, they were not,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Troops Repulse Attack, Kill 26 Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Troops defending a military garrison repulsed a Tamil rebel attack and killed at least 26 guerrillas, officials said Sunday. The Mullaitivu outpost about 173 miles northeast of Colombo has been under seige for 10 weeks, but the troops have held out against repeated mortar attacks. The rebel onslaught Saturday came as the government imposed an indefinite curfew in Mullaitivu, Vavunia and Mannar, predominately Tamil districts in the north. On state-run radio, the government warned residents to stay indoors or risk being shot. Military officials say the curfew could facilitate military operations against the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, the rebel militia fighting since 1983 for a separate nation. The rebels seek a Tamil homeland in northern and eastern districts of the island nation. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people and Sinhalese account for 75 percent. Separatists accuse the Sinhalese-dominated government of discriminating against Tamils in jobs, education and other areas. The latest round of violence flared in June, ending a 13-month cease-fire to help push peace talks. At least 14,000 people have been killed in the seven-year separatist war. In other fighting, rebels killed five soldiers Saturday during an ambush on a military patrol near Kantalai, 130 miles northeast of Colombo, said officials who cannot be identified under briefing rules.

DOC.HEAD: Hospitalized Groom Says Wedding Must Go On
DOC.TEXT: All the invitations had been sent out. The best man and maid of honor arrived in town from Illinois. And the groom was in the hospital with appendicitis. But that didn't stop Bill Sterrett and Rhonda Lochner from getting married Saturday. They just moved the ceremony to the chapel of Cobb Hospital and Medical Center in Austell. Sterrett, recovering from his appendicitis operation the day before, sat in a wheelchair as his bride and their out-of-town wedding party surrounded him in the chapel. He said that after planning a wedding since Dec. 23 _ when he proposed _ he wasn't going to let a little operation sideline him. ``Everybody had come down from Illinois and out of state. People would have been disappointed,'' he said. ``When I talked with the surgeon, he said a lot of people could walk the next day after an appendicitis operation, so we held the wedding here.'' The couple did postpone the honeymoon though _ they're saving that for Thanksgiving.

DOC.HEAD: Government Plans To Hold Power Despite Support For U.N. Peace Plan
DOC.TEXT: The president of Cambodia's Vietnamese-installed government, appearing to reject key features of a new U.N. peace plan, said his government wants to maintain the political and military status quo. The U.S. assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, Richard Solomon, said Sunday that Vietnam had similar reservations in talks with the United States last week. Cambodian President Heng Samrin's comments came in a speech broadcast by the state radio Saturday. The text was seen Sunday in Bangkok. He said his government regarded the U.N. plan ``as a basic document'' for future discussions and was ready to discuss it with the guerrillas in talks Indonesia is arranging. But he said with no elaboration that his government's stance ``is to maintain its status quo _ both politically and military.'' The U.N. role, he said, should include verifying that agreements are implemented and organizing the election. His remarks on the U.N. role were not completely monitored due to reception problems. The plan was adopted Tuesday by the United States and the other permanent members of the Security Council _ China, the Soviet Union, Britain and France. The three rebel groups fighting the government have expressed support for the plan. Washington backs two of the guerrilla groups. On Friday, Cambodia's deputy prime minister in charge of foreign affairs, Hor Nam Hong, said the Phonm Penh government accepted a major U.N. role, including its supervision of certain key ministries. But he gave no indication Cambodia was yielding on its desire for interim authority. They proposed that the United Nations supervise and, if necessary, control five key government ministries in the transitional period before elections. They also want the armies of the Vietnamese-installed Phnom Penh government and the three guerrilla groups disarmed and regrouped into supervised cantonments. The four Cambodian factions would form a ``Supreme National Council'' as a figurehead government. The Cambodian president, in the Saturday broadcast, called the Supreme National Council only ``the symbol of national independence and sovereignty.'' ``The most urgent question is the first meeting of the Supreme National Council so as to enable the voluntary cease-fire to go into effect,'' Heng Samrin said. The guerrillas want either the council or the United Nations as the interim government. An attempt to form the council in June collapsed when the strongest guerrilla group, the Khmer Rouge, opposed the allocation of seats on the council as unfair to it. The final formation of the council is to be a major aim of proposed talks in Indonesia. Soviet-supported Vietnam installed Heng Samrin's Communist government after invading Cambodia in late 1978, ending a nearly four-year Khmer Rouge reign in which hundreds of thousands of people were killed in slave labor camps and execution chambers. The Khmer Rouge, supported by China, now is allied with two non-communist groups in the guerrilla coalition _ the U.S.-backed forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and of Son Sann's Khmer People's National Liberation Front. Vietnam voiced its reservations with the U.N. plan at a meeting at the United Nations Friday in which the United States tried to persuade them to back the plan, Solomon said. The Vietnamese, he said, voiced reservations on ``issues related to military arrangements and some of the administrative arrangements.'' Solomon would not go into detail, but when asked if that meant Vietnam still wanted the armies to remain in place and Phnom Penh to hold interim authority, he replied: ``Yes, my impression is that if they had their own wish, that is probably the case.'' Solomon was in Bangkok for talks on economic issues with Thailand and its five allies in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

DOC.HEAD: Sunday Services Held Despite Ban in Islamic Nation
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Church services were held quietly for American soldiers Sunday despite this country's ban on the practice of religions other than Islam. The services, conducted by chaplains from all military branches, were held in mess halls, tents and in big warehouses. Soldiers said they were well attended. ``There are no atheists in foxholes,'' said Capt. B.A. Arnold, an Air Force chaplain from Cannon Air Force of Clovis, N.M. ``The pressures of the military tend to force people to ask questions about the meaning of life and death.'' The military has gone to great lengths not to draw attention to the services. Notices of times and places are sometimes posted discreetly on bulletin boards; other services are advertised by word of mouth. The military is not alone in circumventing the ban. The Western community holds a Christian service on Fridays _ the traditional day off in Saudi Arabia. The oil company Saudi Aramco, which has thousands of foreign employees, also has Christian services on its private compound. U.S. officials said they do not want to offend the Saudis. ``We do respect the laws of the host country,'' one Pentagon official said. The rule of thumb is: ``Don't flaunt it; Don't try to convert the Moslems,'' Arnold said. Some Americans said they were advised not to bring Bibles to Saudi Arabia or to hand out religious literature. But many people carry Bibles with them, and religious literature is handed out among Marines. A Saudi official said his government is prepared to let people worship as long as they are discreet. The U.S. troops are kept isolated from the Saudi society. Pentagon officials said the religious needs of more than 60,000 military troops deployed here will be met, regardless of whether they are Christian, Jewish or Moslem. The 82nd airborne from Fort Bragg, N.C., for instance, scheduled nine services at its desert headquarters Sunday. All were for Catholics or Protestants, with the exception of one Mormon service. ``Officially there is no religion allowed or practiced in Saudi Arabia other than Islam,'' said Jonathan Rice, a U.S. Consulate spokesman. Americans said the potentially dangerous military situation combined with loneliness and physical hardships have caused them to find solace in religion. Army Pvt. Preston Suminguit says he goes to church ``every chance I get.'' The 20-year-old Cleveland paratrooper pulled from the pockets of his fatigues three things he carries with him at all times: a book of psalms and proverbs from the New Testament; the ``Paratrooper's Faith,'' a collection of religious teachings, and the liner to his father's Green Beret. Airman Ty Worthington, 21, of Base City, Mich., said the practice of religion is sometimes kept out of sight. The chaplains sometimes don't tell the troops about impromptu services until the last minute, he said. ``The services are unseen, unheard ... sometimes in the back of a supply warehouse.'' Even though ``the locals don't like us practicing our religion,'' Worthington said faith plays a big role in the lives of many men and women. The chaplains do a lot of one-on-one work. They handout mail, give out cookies and offer a few words of encouragement. ``I haven't met a paratrooper who is an atheist,'' said Sgt. Derrick White of Patterson, N.J. ``When you are jumping from an aircraft at 2,000 feet you believe in God.''

DOC.HEAD: City Looking For Help As Deficit Looms
DOC.TEXT: The nation's fifth-largest city is running out of cash. Without a $400 million emergency loan, Philadelphia will be out of money by the end of the month. The mayor wants the loan; the city controller says he won't sign it. But even with the cash flow help, the city will still be $206.4 million in the red on a budget of $2.1 billion. And projections indicate more deficits in years to come unless drastic steps are taken. Some are even advocating a state takeover like the one that bailed out New York City 15 years ago. Controller Jonathan A. Saidel can't block the emergency loan by withholding his signature. But he can make it harder for a city whose notes are already rated as shaky by Wall Street. ``I believe it is not in the best interest of the city of Philadelphia,'' Saidel explains. On Friday, Gov. Robert P. Casey said an unidentified Japanese bank had offered the city a $225 million letter of credit to help Philadelphia sell temporary loan notes. Officially, Mayor W. Wilson Goode has put the loan on hold for a couple of weeks to try to sort things out. Saidel said the loan won't cure the debacles that created the crunch, such as the $25 million bill to rebuild a neighborhood bombed by city police in the 1985 confrontation with the radical group MOVE or another $25 million the courts ordered returned to property taxpayers as illegally collected cash. Nor, he said, will it force the mayor and City Council to work together or the state to chip in. Goode blames the crisis on the City Council for blocking his efforts now and in the past, the state Legislature for refusing to allow a local sales tax this year and the federal government for years of decreasing aid. He made a televised appeal last month for more state aid and council cooperation in raising unspecified existing taxes $150 million and cutting unspecified ``non-essential'' city services. Without those steps, despite the $400 million loan, the city will run out of cash next May. The mayor's approach is not new. For three years, the council has diluted or rejected his calls for more taxes and the state has rebuffed many of his requests for more aid. Some think this time will be different. ``The problem is so real, so pressing that no one is going to be able to avoid it,'' said Sandra Featherman, director of the Center for Public Policy at Temple University. Others think the mayor and council will reach their usual stalemate and look to an outside group to rescue the city. ``More and more there's a belief, especially in the business community, that there has to be an outside entity, that there has to be credibility established,'' said G. Terry Madonna, director of the Center for Politics and Public Affairs at Millersville University. On television, Goode said he would name an advisory panel to devise ``hard-hitting'' solutions. But it would have no authority to act. Backers of outside control point to the successful state and federal rescue of New York City, which in 1975 was broke and $792 million in debt. The New York Legislature established the Municipal Assistance Corp. to monitor the city budget and sell bonds on its behalf. An Emergency Financial Control Board was later given control of the city's spending and eventually won the confidence of lending institutions. The federal government backed up $2.3 billion in city borrowing. Philadelphia officials have so far brushed off the idea, unwilling to surrender control. As for state officials, Featherman said, ``I'm not sure the state wants the problem of managing Philadelphia's debt.'' Madonna said getting more state aid won't be easy, especially in an election year. ``There's the perception that the city gets more than its share of state aid, of having to fund the excesses of the city, that the Goode administration has been less than competent,'' he said. Further, until there is a workable plan backed by Goode and the council, aiding Philadelphia ``will be perceived as throwing money down a rat hole.''

DOC.HEAD: Gephardt: Limits To US Patience, But Time More Saddam's Problem
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto BAH1
DOC.TEXT: House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt said Sunday that a lengthy U.S. military presence in Saudi Arabia might strain the American public's patience, but that time will be a worse enemy to Saddam Huseein. The Missouri Democrat led a 22-member congressional delegation in a visit to American troops, a visit that was shortened when a C-130 Hercules transport plane developed mechanical trouble. The breakdown, details of which were not immediately available, forced the delegation to cancel one planned trip to a Marine camp in the northeast Saudi desert. In a brief session with reporters before heading out to see the troops, Gephardt said there would be ``limits to our patience'' back home if the deployment dragged on. But with Iraq facing world condemnation for its invasion of Kuwait and economic sanctions that have forced food rationing in Iraq, Gephardt suggested the United States had more time than Saddam. ``There's a patience problem on the Iraqi side as well,'' said Gephardt. ``It's the world against him _ it's not the world against us.'' For now, Gephardt said of the mood back home: ``I've never seen stronger support for a military operation since I've been in Congress.'' He was first elected to the House in 1976. The commander of U.S. forces in the Middle East, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, also cited the rationing as evidence the embargo was taking its toll on Baghdad. ``During all eight years of the Iran-Iraq war they never went to rationing,'' Schwarzkopf said. Gephardt said a briefing by Schwarzkopf convinced him the United States has a formidable deterrent force in place. But he said the United States was still in a ``waiting game'' as the remainder of its deployment headed for the Middle East. In what is becoming a familiar chorus from members of Congress, Gephardt called on other nations to join the multinational defense force. ``We've got to convince some of the other nations that they've got to come in,'' he said. Some U.S. allies outside the region have sent warships, minesweepers and fighter jets, and some Arab countries have deployed troops. The delegation met with the 1st Tactical Fighter Wing, which brought dozens of F-15s from the United States to Saudi Arabia, and then members of the 101st Airborne Division's air-assault brigade. The chief complaint from the troops was a poor mail system. ``There sure are a lot of bugs to be worked out,'' Pvt. Edward Humelhans of Suring, Wis., told Rep. David Obey, a Democrat from the same state. Other congressional delegations have visited the troops in the Saudi desert in recent days. Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Claiborne Pell led one over the weekend and eight senators came earlier last week. U.S. congressmen also visited sailors Saturday aboard the USS La Salle.

DOC.HEAD: Head of Women's Commission Recounts Story of Sexual Assault
DOC.TEXT: The director of the state's Permanent Commission on the Status of Women has come forward to tell her story of being raped two years ago, saying in a detailed newspaper account that she spoke out because rape is a ``crime of silence.'' ``I want people to understand it, I want people to understand that it's an act of violence and I want people to know that it doesn't have a damn thing to do with sex,'' Fredrica Gray said in an interview with The Hartford Courant published Sunday. Gray, the executive director of the commission, was sexually assaulted on Feb. 3, 1988, in her home in Bloomfield, a Hartford suburb. She said she convinced her attacker that she had AIDS _ a lie _ and lured him back to her house, telling him she had medicine to treat the condition. When the man returned, he was arrested. The man, Johnny B. Williams of Hartford, pleaded no-contest and was sentenced earlier this year to 13 years in prison. ``For every Johnny, there are a million other ones, other men who commit these crimes and a lot of them are never caught,'' Gray said. Gray, 44, said she hoped her account would focus more attention on violence against women and encourage more victims of sexual assalt to report such crimes. In publishing Gray's story, the Courant broke with its policy of not printing the names of rape victims. While most newspapers have similar policies, the issue has been debated in journalistic circles recently, especially after The Des Moines (Iowa) Register printed stories earlier this year naming a woman who came forward with the story of her 1989 rape. As a women's rights activist, Gray had previously helped write a booklet on procedures for gathering evidence in rape cases. At the time of the attack, she was preparing for hearings on new statewide procedures for dealing with rape victims. Still, she said, the attack left her devastated. Even after Williams' arrest, she received mail from him. At one point, she said, he sent her ``extremely gross'' pornography; in another letter, he wrote, ``I love you very much. I want to come home,'' she said. ``It was like being assaulted again and again,'' she said. She sold her house 16 months after the attack. ``I never could sleep there again,'' she said. ``There's something that happens about the place you live, the place in which you are assaulted. You can't live there, you can't feel safe there. It re-traumatizes you every time you walk through the door.'' Gray caught her attacker through an elaborate lie she told him during the attack, which occurred when she was home sick from her work at the commission. ``I said to him, `You know why I'm home? I have AIDS. ... If you don't believe me, there's medicine on my dresser,'' she said. When the attacker asked if he could call her later, Gray said, she gave him a false name and her real phone number. ``I wanted him to call the house,'' she said. ``Because I knew that if I could get him to call me that we would have a pretty good chance of apprehending him.'' The day after the assault, Gray waited with a police detective, and the attacker called again. To lure him back to the house for medicine, she told him, ``You may have raped me, but I'm going to live, and you're going to die.'' Williams, then 22, was arrested soon after he entered the house.

DOC.HEAD: Groups Calls for Outright Ban on Cancer-Causing Pesticides
DOC.TEXT: An environmental group said Sunday the government should gradually halt the use of many cancer-causing chemicals on food because it cannot measure how many of the substances a person may consume. In a report, the non-governmental U.S. Public Interest Research Group said that as many as 60 cancer-causing pesticides can legally used on the most commonly eaten foods under Environmental Protection Agency rules. But the EPA does not adequately account for the accumulated exposure to such pesticides through consumption of various foods, the report said. Critics also maintain that some levels are based on outdated health and medical information. ``Rather than ban a chemical, the EPA uses the inexact science of risk assessment to set very politicized standards for carcinogens and declares the risks `negligible','' said the report. An EPA spokesman, Al Heier, said that the report reflected nothing new and that the agency three years ago published a list of cancer-causing chemicals in foods. He said that the EPA is reviewing the status of scores of such chemicals that are used as long as residue levels remain within specific limits. Rick Tinsworth, director of the EPA's review efforts, said the direction in which the EPA is going ``parallels what they (the environmentalists) are suggesting.'' He said the EPA hopes by 1997 to have reviewed the status of some 400 pesticides and determine whether they should remain in use. The PIRG report documents to what extent cancer-causing pesticides are being used on a variety of commonly eaten foods from beef and pork to vegetables and dairy products. ``Ten of these commonly eaten foods surveyed are allowed to contain 20 or more of these carcinogens,'' said the report. It noted that 32 different types of cancer-causing pesticides can be used on beef, 30 types on pork, and 20 or more types on poultry, peaches, grapes, eggs, tomatoes, apples, milk and corn. The report acknowledged that a farmer would not use all of these pesticides on a single crop, perhaps choosing one or a combination of several, instead. ``The point is that if it did occur it would be legal,'' wrote Rick Hind, U.S. PIRG's environmental director, in the report. Hind said the correct answer to protecting health is the ``systematic and orderly phaseout'' of the cancer-causing chemicals. He noted some supermarkets already have suggested a phaseout. The report suggested that the most menacing of the cancer-causing pesticides be banned over the next eight years. So far, it noted, the EPA has banned only 11 pesticides for all uses on foods. The U.S. PIRG report also urged that pesticide manufacturers be required to develop better monitoring procedures and that the companies be required to prove that a chemical is safe, instead of the government proving it unsafe, for it to remain on the market. It noted that farm legislation before Congress would require farmers to keep records of their pesticide use and would ban the export of pesticides prohibited for domestic use. There are numerous cases where imported foods contain pesticides that are not allowed on foods produced in this country, according to various recent studies.

DOC.HEAD: Conservative House Member Seen as Man to Beat in Senate Race
DOC.TEXT: Bob Smith's critics paint him as a pedestrian congressman who would make a lackluster senator, but the three-term Republican is seen as the man to beat for New Hampshire's open U.S. Senate seat. Smith is a staunch conservative who's sometimes set himself at odds with party leaders _ most notably in fighting congressional pay raises. He brushes aside criticism of his track record in the House. ``You focus on your principles and stick to them,'' says Smith, 49. ``Otherwise, why serve?'' The Senate seat will open up because Republican Gordon Humphrey is leaving after two terms, fulfilling his pledge not to make Congress a career. It is one of only three open Senate seats that will be filled in the 1990 elections. National GOP leaders want to keep the seat in Republican hands even at the price of creating friction within the party. A who's who of New Hampshire's GOP faithful, including White House chief of staff and former Gov. John Sununu, has lined up behind Smith in the four-way Republican primary on Sept. 11. Vice President Dan Quayle in May appeared at a Smith fund-raiser in Washington as pleas for neutrality from one of the congressman's GOP rivals, 42-year-old lawyer Thomas Christo, when unheeded. ``The kind of person who puts a lot of stock in the party hierarchy and the status quo is not going to be with me,'' Christo said. Also vying for the GOP nomination are engineering professor Ted de Winter, 57; and businessman Ewing Smith, 68. Smith holds an ultraconservative voting record on spending issues and says he'd continue to fight for a balanced-budget amendment and elimination of the federal budget deficit if elected to the Senate. ``Everybody accuses me of being too simplistic on this, but there is nothing complicated about it at all. You have to agree in principle to balance the budget,'' he said. Some rivals say Smith's consistent support for military spending belies his claim to be a skinflint. Smith's America ``is a land in which hundreds of billions are spent on Star Wars while the homeless live in cardboard boxes, senior citizens fear cutbacks in Social Security and America's children must go without school lunches,'' said Democrat James Donchess, the Nashua mayor. Smith says he favors some defense cuts, but backs continued funding for the Strategic Defense Initiative _ Star Wars _ and the B2 bomber. Competing for the Democratic nomination are Donchess, 41; former U.S. Sen. John Durkin, 54; and millionaire former businessman John Rauh, 58. The Democratic aspirants may have hoped Smith's primary rivals would bloody him before the general election, but they've been busy bruising each other instead. Durkin confronted Donchess at a recent news conference, then followed him to a series of news conferences around the state. At each stop, they called each other names. The next day, Rauh denounced their actions. Smith stands alone in the field in his strong opposition to abortion, a stand his opponents have criticized repeatedly. But Smith recently modified his position, saying he would accept abortion not only to protect the life of the mother, but in cases of rape and incest as well. In an August poll conducted by the University of New Hampshire for WMUR-TV in Manchester, 43 percent of Republicans backed Smith. Six percent chose Christo; 2 percent, Ewing Smith; and 1 percent, de Winter. Forty-eight percent were undecided. Among Democrats, 36 percent backed Durkin; 18 percent, Donchess; 9 percent, Rauh; and 37 percent undecided. The margin of error was 5 percentage points. Smith outpolled all three Democrats in head-to-head matchups by comfortable margins in an earlier poll by the Becker Institute of Sudbury, Mass. Only Smith and Rauh, a newcomer to politics, declined to abide by New Hampshire's voluntary campaign spending limit of $400,000 in the primary and a like amount in the general election campaign. Smith said the combined spending of the others in a bid to derail him prevents him from sticking to the limit. He scoffs at rivals' claims that his acceptance of political action committee money means his vote is for sale. ``No PAC has ever asked me for my vote and I would not give it to them,'' he says.

DOC.HEAD: Acting Nevada Governor Favored Over 13 Would-Be Successors
DOC.TEXT: Acting Gov. Bob Miller inherited his job without being elected and critics paint his two-year tenure as undistinguished, but he's heavily favored over 13 Democratic and Republican would-be successors. Democrat Miller, who got the governor's job when then-Gov. Dick Bryan jumped to the U.S. Senate in 1988, is being challenged by five Democrats in Tuesday's primary. All are little known and running limited campaigns, including one long-shot hopeful who changed his name to Rhinestone Cowboy. The Republican ballot is even more crowded. There are eight candidates led by Jim Gallaway, a relative newcomer to the state who says Miller has shown ``a total lack of leadership'' as acting governor. Gallaway's campaign got a boost when the Marine reserve colonel was called up for a brief stint on active duty last month. Gallaway, who had served five years on active duty, spent a week in Arlington, Va., working as a logistics coordinator on the gulf crisis before returning to the campaign trail. Gallaway has been accused by another GOP contender, builder Charlie Brown, of trying to buy the election with slick television ads. Gallaway has outspent Brown by a four-to-one margin. None of the other Republican candidates, each a political unknown, has mounted a major campaign. A Tarrance & Associates poll conducted for the Nevada Retailers Association in August looked at the likely matchup in November and found Miller trouncing Gallaway 60 percent to 27 percent, with a 4 percentage point margin of error. But Gallaway, a business entrepreneur, said his internal polls show him gaining an edge on the governor when voters are told Gallaway favors abortion rights and opposes a statewide payroll tax plan while Miller is anti-abortion and backs the tax. Miller, 45, was elected lieutenant governor four years ago after serving two terms in Las Vegas as Clark County district attorney. He takes credit as governor for getting lawmakers to raise teachers' pay and lower class sizes and creating a state drug ``czar.'' He also has vetoed a controversial pension hike for lawmakers, supported various tax hikes, and opposed abortion. ``I'm optimistic,'' Miller said of his election campaign. ``I'm going to run based on my record.'' He said that includes his two years as governor as well as his prior service as lieutenant governor and in Las Vegas, where he was raised. Gallaway has attacked Miller on his abortion and taxation stands, but the governor so far has avoided direct criticism of Gallaway and the other candidates. ``I'm busy talking about Bob Miller,'' the governor said. ``In fact, from the campaign activity I've seen, it looks like both of us are going to be talking about me.'' Miller has collected $1.1 million in contributions compared with Gallaway's total of about $318,000, most of that from his personal funds. But Gallaway said he's hoping for another $1 million and is willing to continue pouring his own money into the race. Gallaway said that while he has been in Nevada only about two years, he has strong GOP support, including backing from the Republican Governor's Association. All that Miller can show for his tenure is ``a total lack of leadership. The only time he acts is in a crisis,'' Gallaway said.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomatic Setback After U.N.-Iraq Talks Fail To Produce Results
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Diplomatic efforts to avert war slipped back out of the public eye Sunday as U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar voiced deep disappointment that talks with Iraq reached no accord over Kuwait. ``I had hoped for a more flexible position regarding the retreat ... from Kuwait,'' Perez de Cuellar said, briefing reporters after nine hours of talks over two days with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. In a prepared statement, he concluded: ``The talks were useful, but disappointing.'' Later he flew to Paris, where he was to meet with Jordan's King Hussein and French President Francois Mitterrand. The Jordanian king has traveled to nine countries to gather support for an Arab peace plan he has yet to crystallize. In Paris, Perez de Cuellar said he was ``deeply disappointed'' in his talks with Aziz because he had expected ``a certain flexibility.'' ``What Iraq wants is to stay in Kuwait, which is unacceptable to the international community, to the U.N. Security Council and to its secretary general,'' Perez de Cuellar told reporters after meeting French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas. But he said he still held out hope that Iraq would become more accommodating. ``I am available,'' he said. ``If, at any given time, they wish to modify their position, I will be delighted to listen to them.'' Although a summit in Helsinki next Sunday between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev might open new possibilities, no other major public talks on the Persian Gulf crisis were scheduled. Perez de Cuellar began the highly touted Amman meetings Friday with uncharacteristic optimism, matched by upbeat remarks by Aziz. Both also reflected a positive attitude between their four sessions. But a senior Jordanian official with access to the talks said the meeting broke down over Iraq's refusal to budge on the basic issue of its domination of Kuwait, which it seized on Aug. 2. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Perez de Cuellar had hoped for some public concession from Iraq, along with its quiet moves beneath the surface. ``Iraq had many demands and was stubborn,'' the official said. ``Aziz spent much of his time insisting the United States was violating international law.'' With hopes dashed for any immediate breakthrough, Perez de Cuellar would likely explore various proposals for an Arab buffer force under an international umbrella, the Jordanian official said. The buffer force would separate U.S. and allied troops from Iraqi troops. Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi has suggested his own peace plan, under which U.N. troops would replace the Iraqis in Kuwait and Arab or Moslem armies would replace U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia. PLO chief Yasser Arafat has proposed a plan that links an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait with an Israeli pullout from occupied territories. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak's Arab League approach simply demands that Iraq leave Kuwait. Perez de Cuellar said the crisis had taken on international dimensions and ``global principles have to be acknowledged.'' But with international approval, he said, any Arab plan could be implemented. Asked about the use of an Arab force, Perez de Cuellar told reporters, ``I did not discuss this with him.'' But Jordanian sources said Aziz and the U.N. chief discussed a plan to put Arab troops between Iraqi and U.S. forces, secure release of the hostages and arrange for simultaneous withdrawals in Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. U.N. members, including the Soviet Union, might mediate. But, the sources said, the long-term political resolution of the conflict seemed insurmountable. Iraq has stressed that any solution in Kuwait must also settle outstanding issues in Israeli-occupied territories and Lebanon, where Syrian troops are deployed. In the Amman talks, Aziz refused to bend until guarantees were made about Israel and Lebanon, the Jordanian sources said. The secretary-general, as an agent of the United Nations, had no room to maneuver, they said.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Ambassador Reported Taken from Kuwait to Baghdad
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An East German government spokesman said the country's ambassador to Kuwait was forcibly taken to Iraq on Sunday after he left his diplomatic mission, apparently to seek food at the West German Embassy. The East Berlin government was negotiating with Iraq for the release of Ambassador Kurt Merkel, 56, a government spokesman said on condition of anonymity. The spokesman, citing the talks with Iraq, would give no details of the incident. However, he confirmed a report from Brussels, Belgium, where a diplomatic source said Merkel was taken to Baghdad from Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. The source, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, said the information was relayed to Brussels by Marcel van Roey, the Belgian ambassador in Kuwait. The source said the East German envoy left his embassy ``where the food and water situation was apparently critical,'' to visit the West German Embassy. After leaving the West German mission Saturday afternoon, Merkel, accompanied by his wife, was questioned by Iraqi soldiers for several hours, the Belgian official said. ``He spent the night at the East German mission. Today (Sunday), he was taken under escort to Baghdad. This sounds like an expulsion to us,'' added the source. It was unclear if Merkel's wife also was taken to Baghdad. A West German Foreign Ministry spokesman in Bonn said he could not confirm the report and said the information must come from East Germany. Merkel has been ambassador to Kuwait since April 22, 1987. He and his wife had been alone at the embassy since the mission's 15 other staffers were evacuated more than a week ago. Iraq has ordered foreign missions to leave Kuwait because it claims the country is now a part of Iraq. Scores of diplomats remain holed up in their embassies. A West German jet early Sunday carried 311 women, children and a few men from 22 countries to Frankfurt from Iraq after Baghdad said it would release women and children among the Westerners trapped in the country. Iraq is the target of a U.S.-led trade embargo that is believed to have created shortages of food and other essential supplies. Thousands of U.S. troops were deployed in Saudi Arabia to deter an Iraqi attack after the Persian Gulf nation invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: August's Death Toll Equals Lowest In Arab Uprising
DOC.TEXT: Three Palestinians were killed by Israelis in August, equaling the lowest monthly death toll of the 33-month Palestinian uprising, according to figures released Sunday. July's toll was also three. The Israeli Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories attributed the lower toll to an army policy of avoiding confrontations with stone- throwers. The policy was initiated by Defense Minister Moshe Arens, who took office in June. ``The decrease in the number of (Palestinians) killed by the security forces in the territories continues,'' the center said in a written statement. ``It can be explained by a more restrained policy on opening fire.'' Of the three Palestinians killed in August, one victim was shot in a clash with soldiers in the occupied West Bank. Also, an Israeli woman has been charged in connection with the death of a Palestinian during anti-Arab riots in Jerusalem. The army said an investigation is being conducted into the fatal shooting of a Palestinian woman in the West Bank town of Hebron. The slayings in Jerusalem and Hebron followed the discovery of the bodies of two Jewish teen-agers in Jerusalem, believed to be slain by Palestinian nationalists. Also in August, Palestinians in the occupied territories killed at least 11 fellow Arabs on suspicion of collaborating with the Israeli authorities, Arab reports said. At least 728 Palestinians have died at the hands of Israeli soldiers and civilians since the uprising began in December 1987. The highest toll was in April 1988, when 44 Palestinians were killed during riots over the death of the Palestine Liberation Organization's military commander, Khalil Wazir, also known as Abu Jihad. He was shot in Tunis by unidentified assailants. The death was blamed on Israel. Last May, 32 Palestinians were killed, most as the army sought to put down riots following the killings of seven Arab workers by an apparently deranged Israeli civilian. Some 254 Palestinians also have been killed by their Arab brethren as suspected pro-Israeli collaborators. Forty-seven Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS Detroit-dated 3rd item to DELETE reference to President Bush being at Ellis Island; he will be at Helsinki summit.
DOC.TEXT: Lee Iacocca, preparing to reopen New York's Ellis Island next weekend, says the racial melting pot is what makes America work. ``Whether it's food, or dress, or the arts, music, whatever,'' he said. ``If we're losing control of our destiny, it's because we aren't facing up to our heritage. And what's that? Back to Ellis Island.'' The Chrysler Corp. chairman led the drive to raise $345 million to restore Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty, which was rededicated in 1986. Next Sunday, Iacocca will help dedicate the new Ellis Island Immigration Museum and designate the 27-acre site on the island in New York Harbor as a national shrine. Immigrants have learned hard work and sacrifice are keys to a better life, Iacocca said. Iacocca, an immigrant's son, said the gateway to the United States for 17 million Americans can give the country a needed boost of morale. But the Ellis Island celebration will be low-key _ dinner and speeches _ compared to the hoopla of the statue four years ago. ``One guy called me and said, `What are you, crazy? Why are we having a black-tie dinner? Is that in keeping with the immigrant experience?' I said, `What do you want, for us to come in rags?''' Iacocca said. ``I just thought it would be a nice touch, and you do honor to the fact that we made it _ we can even afford to rent a tux.''

DOC.HEAD: 21 Killed in Attacks in Two Townships
DOC.TEXT: Police found the bodies of 21 blacks Sunday following overnight clashes in townships wracked by fighting among rival black factions. President F.W. de Klerk, meanwhile, announced a follow-up investigation into allegations of improper police violence against blacks and urged an inquiry into the system of housing migrant workers in barracks. Many of the young men in the barracks have taken part in township fights in which more than 530 blacks have died since Aug. 12. The battles in Tembisa and Tokoza east of Johannesburg Saturday came after a week of relative peace in the townships. Men armed with guns and other weapons drove around the townships late Saturday night in a van, firing at pedestrians and getting out to attack, said police spokesman Capt. Eugene Opperman. The victims had been shot or hacked to death, Opperman said. The townships are about 18 miles apart. Most of the recent fighting has pitted Zulus loyal to the conservative Inkatha movement against Xhosas and other blacks who support the African National Congress, led by Nelson Mandela. ANC leaders, speaking at a mass funeral Sunday, accused police of siding with Inkatha in the recent clashes. About 4,000 people attended the service at a soccer stadium for 19 blacks killed in Kagiso, west of Johannesburg. Alfred Nzo, the ANC's secretary general, said the victims ``died at the hands of the agents of the apartheid regime.'' De Klerk and police have said individual policemen may have acted improperly, but the force as a whole has been impartial. The speakers pleaded for tolerance among opposing black organizations. But the youthful crowd shouted down a Kagiso town councilor and a member of the Pan-Africanist Congress, a rival group. Militant blacks consider black town leaders collaborators with the white-led government.
