De Klerk requested Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok to conduct ``an urgent and in-depth investigation'' after a government report concluded police fired without reason on black demonstrators last March, killing five and wounding 156 in Sebokeng south of Johannesburg. ``Certain allegations which have been made against the South African police are regarded in an extremely serious light,'' de Klerk said. The ANC, which claims more than 10 people were killed at the Sebokeng shooting, called the report's findings an example of the ``indiscipline, callousness and readiness to shoot on the part of the police.'' De Klerk also announced an inquiry into the system of migrant-worker hostels for young, single men. He said the government wants to provide housing on a ``family basis'' but cannot because of a severe housing shortage among blacks. ``These hostels cannot simply be closed or demolished without alternative accommodation being available,'' said de Klerk.

DOC.HEAD: Future Cloudy For Embattled Wilderness Survival Program
DOC.TEXT: The embattled founder of a desert-survival program for wayward teens is fighting state efforts to close him down, possibly as early as this week, and criminal charges stemming from the death of a 16-year-old charge. Stephen Cartisano says the negligent homicide and child abuse charges are part of a vendetta by state officials, ``liars'' jealous of his Challenger Foundation's success. He says he may just pick up and move to another state. ``I have more success than these guys can ever dream about,'' Cartisano has said. ``They want to put me out of business because they think they are the sole repositories of light and truth regarding children.'' The sniping against the founder of the Delaware-based company became a barrage this summer with the heat stroke death of a teen-age girl enrolled in the Challenger program, and with allegations by other teen-agers of being abused, starved, tied up and forced to eat lizards and mice to survive. Cartisano's critics describe him as a manipulator who places profit above concern for his young patients. The program charges $15,900 for its 63-day ``expedition.'' ``Basically, he charges parents a lot of money to take their kids out in the desert and feed them roadkill,'' said Terry Twitchell, a spokeswoman with the state Department of Human Services. ``He's a liar,'' said Dr. Kay Edrington, a former Challenger employee who claims Cartisano misrepresented him to parents and on insurance billing forms as a psychologist. ``I've known for some time there would come a day of reckoning for Challenger,'' Edrington said. It may be coming soon. A state judge ordered the beleaguered program to come up with a $100,000 bond by Tuesday to prove its financial ability to continue business. Without it, the judge threatens to shut the program down. In Kane County, Sheriff Max Jackson has filed a misdemeanor negligent homicide count against Cartisano and his former field director, Lance ``Horsehair'' Jagger, in the June 27 death of Kristen Chase, 16. Eight other counts of misdemeanor child abuse also were filed against the two men. They are scheduled for arraignment Sept. 13. Challenger this summer sought protection under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code and claims assets of only $63,000. State officials say Challenger owes more than $279,000 in federal and state taxes. Cartisano said he is considering leaving Utah for less hostile surroundings. ``I've had offers from southern Nevada, New Mexico and Arizona,'' he said. ``I hate to say, `You won't have Steve Cartisano to kick around anymore,' but it's getting to that point.'' Yet, some parents _ even the mother of the girl who died _ support Cartisano's austere recipe for bringing, as program literature puts it, ``defiant, irresponsible or rebellious teen-agers out of their dream world and back to reality.'' ``Sometimes we need to be a little more calloused instead of pampering our little darling dumplings like we've been doing and not making them responsible for their own behavior,'' said Judith Tepper of Los Angeles. Her teen-age son, Jordan, reportedly was tied to a tree by Challenger counselors after trying to flee the program and dragged through the brush when he refused to hike. Another advocate is Sharon Fuqua of Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., Kristen's mother. The girl collapsed and died of heat stroke while hiking atop the rugged Kaiparowits Plateau. ``I've never met any more dedicated, loving people trying to help children,'' she said after her daughter's death. Cartisano said Chase's death can't be blamed on his program. ``She could have walked over to Central Park and collapsed,'' he said at the time. Challenger opened in 1988, an offshoot of a popular survival program offered at Brigham Young University in the 1970s. That program was based on the idea that troubled youth could be helped if forced to cope _ and triumph _ in an unforgiving environment that cannot be manipulated. Some believe Challenger has skewed those goals, using the desert not as a lesson but as a tool for punishment. During a recent court hearing, attorneys described interviews of Challenger patients. One teen related a practice called ``rodeo,'' described as ``punishment where they run until they couldn't run, hike until they couldn't hike and then crawl until they couldn't crawl _ and then they were dragged.'' Several said they weren't given any food for up to four days when entering the program and were forced to forage for meals. Assistant Utah Attorney General Linda Luinstra said a 15-year-old boy related that ``at one point he ate a lizard and at another, he and some other children skinned a mouse and ate it.'' Nine wilderness survival programs operate in Utah and officials estimate that as many as 300 teen-agers hike and climb the breathtaking vistas of southern Utah's red-rock desert, seeking a solution to problems of drug abuse, laziness and low self-esteem. The programs came under scrutiny after the deaths of Chase and another girl, 15-year-old Michelle Sutton of Pleasanton, Calif., who died while enrolled in a similar program, Summit Quest, earlier this summer. State officials have dogged Challenger since its inception, but up until now have succeeded only in forcing the program to obtain a state license. Challenger was granted a provisional, 90-day license on July 1. Ken Stettler, deputy director of the Division of Licensing, promises it won't be renewed without ``radical'' changes. Cartisano boasts a 93 percent success rate. Children are returned to the program _ at no additional cost _ if they get into trouble before they turn 18.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Apologizes in Court-Ordered Ads For False Rape Charge
DOC.TEXT: A woman who falsely accused a man of rape apologized Sunday in court-ordered radio ads, saying she hopes time will heal the damage to the man's reputation. Elizabeth Irene Richardson, 24, was ordered to run radio and newspaper ads throughout Dawson County in central Nebraska as part of her sentence for a perjury conviction last February. She was later to begin a six-month jail term for falsely accusing Gary Nitsch, 44. ``I want the public to know that these allegations were not true and that I made up the story for personal reasons,'' Ms. Richardson said in the radio ad. ``While I realize there is nothing I can really do or say to repair the damage I have caused, I sincerely pray that time will heal the wounds my false allegations have inflicted on Mr. Nitsch and his family,'' she said. Ms. Richardson accused Nitsch of raping her in September 1988. He was charged with sexual assault, but the case was dropped for lack of physical evidence. Authorities later learned that Ms. Richardson had told friends the rape was a hoax. Dawson County Attorney John Marsh said Ms. Richardson was trying to get the attention of her husband, a truck driver who was often away from home. Nitsch said he had met the woman briefly when he went to her house inquiring about a painting job she had advertised. As a result of the false charge, Nitsch lost his job and his family was harassed. A Dawson County District Court judge sentenced Ms. Richardson to apologize in a half-page advertisement in every newspaper and a primetime spot on each radio station in Dawson County. The county in central Nebraska has about 22,000 residents. Nitsch does not have a telephone, and a message was left Sunday at his brother's home. The woman who answered said Nitsch was working and not available.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait Offers Financial Aid to Hostage Families
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait is promising financial assistance to American families facing money problems because of Iraq's holding of their loved ones in Kuwait, the Kuwaiti Embassy confirmed Sunday. It was unclear whether any money had yet been provided any of the families or how much financial assistance was involved. The embassy did not mention families of American workers held in Iraq. ``We stand ready, willing and are able to share in the costs whatever we are asked for by these families,'' Kuwaiti Ambassador Saud Nasir al-Sabah said in a statement. ``All families who are currently in the U.S. and who are facing economic or financial difficulties because of their husbands or relatives are being held hostage by the Iraqis inside Kuwait will receive assistance from the government of Kuwait,'' al-Sabah said. He said the assistance would be coordinated through the U.S. State Department. But the State Department on Sunday referred questions about the assistance promise to the Kuwaiti Embassy. One department official, speaking on the condition that he not be identified further, said he was not aware of any payments having been made, but ``we're aware they made the offer.'' There have been a number of reports of immediate families of Americans being held by Iraq facing financial difficulties. At least one oil drilling company whose business with Kuwait or Iraq has been disrupted stopped paying the salaries of 16 workers, who were in the two countries when the crisis erupted a month ago. One of the first actions by President Bush in response to the Iraqi invasions of Kuwait was to freeze all Iraqi and Kuwaiti assets in the United States. The exiled Kuwaiti government, however, has been given access to funds. The Kuwaiti Embassy said the Kuwaiti government ``has become concerned about the plight of many of these American families who have lost their income.'' There are an estimated 2,500 Americans in Kuwait and as many as 500 in Iraq. While some of them have had their families with them, many others working in oil fields were in Kuwait alone with wives and children back in the United States. Most large companies are believed to have continued paying the workers, but some have not. A small Texas company, OGE Drilling Inc. of Houston, fired its 16 workers in Kuwait the day of the Iraqi invasion. ``Our contracts with these people ended by basis of ... an act of war, something beyond our control,'' OGE Vice President Jay Simpson said recently. Simpson said the company, which supplies workers for the Kuwait Oil Co., could not afford to continue paying the workers' salaries with revenue no longer coming from the Kuwaiti company. Ten of OGE's workers have escaped Kuwait, but six reportedly continue to be held. One of the six workers, Edward Hale, was believed to have been among the first Americans detained by the Iraqis. His wife, Patricia, was stunned when told she no longer would be getting her husband's paycheck. She said she faces serious money problems. The Kuwaiti Embassy said the State Department will seek out the families and determine who might need assistance.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS first two grafs of first item to CLARIFY 47 Americans freed. No first add will move.
DOC.TEXT: Forty-seven Americans reclaimed their freedom Sunday, liberated from Saddam Hussein's clutches and grateful to be back home. ``I wasn't a guest,'' said Lloyd Culbertson. ``I damned near starved to death.'' The former hostages, weary from 24 hours of travel and their weeks as unofficial prisoners of war, arrived at Washington-Dulles International Airport aboard an Iraqi jetliner cleared to land only for this homecoming flight. Just a handful of the passengers talked with reporters; most cleared customs and left the airport quietly with relatives. A U.S. official said 24 women, 11 men and 12 children arrived but declined to identify them, citing privacy laws. The Americans who were held in Kuwait, which was overrun by Iraqi soldiers on Aug. 2, brought ominous word that Saddam Hussein's forces may be mistreating Americans left behind.

DOC.HEAD: Holmes a Court, Once Richest Man Down Under, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Robert Holmes a Court, the cunning corporate raider once known as Australia's richest man, died of a heart attack Sunday. He was 53. Family spokesman Tim Treadgold said the businessman was rushed to a hospital early Sunday from his family farm outside Perth, on Australia's west coast, but was dead on arrival. ``It was totally unexpected. As far as I know, there had been no indications he had heart trouble,'' Treadgold said. Holmes a Court, born in Johannesburg, South Africa, was known as a shrewd but polite, soft-spoken entrepreneur who had been rebuilding his financial empire after losing much of his estimated $1.4 billion fortune in the October 1987 stock market crash. ``In many respects, he revolutionized the finance world in Australia,'' said Ian Spicer, the chief executive of the Confederation of Australian Industry. ``He was a dominant character, a man of significant ability, and he will be missed in the business community.'' The former attorney made his reputation as a corporate raider, earning the nickname of the ``Great Acquirer'' while chairman of the Bell Resources Group. He built it into an empire based on rising asset values in transportation, media, entertainment and building supplies. Holmes a Court amassed a stake of nearly $1 billion in U.S. oil giant Texaco Inc., had large interests in the British bank Standard Chartered and American steelmaker USX Corp., and made four unsuccessful bids for BHP, Australia's largest company. BHP, which stands for Broken Hill Proprietary, is a steel, oil and mining giant. His diversified holdings also included two newspapers, a Perth television station and a radio network. Bell's assets topped out at about $6 billion. But the 1987 crash hit Holmes a Court hard, costing him an estimated $1 billion when Merrill Lynch and Co. withdrew as lead manager of a major bond issue that Bell would have used to reduce its interest payments. Investors' confidence was shaken. Holmes a Court was forced to sell off many of assets, including about half his controlling stake in Bell, to an arm of the West Australia state government and the rest to business rival Alan Bond. While down, Holmes a Court was not out. He chose to foresake the public corporate scene and concentrate on his Perth-based private flagship company, Heytesbury Holdings Ltd. In May, he became Australia's largest landowner when he bought control of the country's biggest cattle ranch, Sherwin Pastoral. The company leases an area about the size of England and Wales combined _ about 1 percent of Australia's entire land mass. Australian Business Magazine reported that his personal wealth swelled by 66 percent last year to $500 million, calling it a ``tribute to his ability to salvage a personal fortune from a public debacle.'' He also owned stables of racehorses, an extensive art collection and several antique cars. Holmes a Court is survived by his wife, Janet, and four children. There was no immediate information about funeral arrangements.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Scrambles to Prepare for Gorbachev Meeting
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's hastily called summit with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev will likely consist of about five hours of talks devoted largely to the Persian Gulf crisis, administration officials said Sunday. ``We're comparing notes. We would be explaining where we think the situation is, where we would go,'' one source said, describing the discussion as similiar to the ongoing consultations Bush has had with several other world leaders on the crisis. On Saturday when he announced the summit, Bush said the gulf crisis was one of many items to be discussed. ``There is no special agenda relating to the Middle East,'' he said. The meeting is scheduled for next Sunday in Helsinki, Finland. Although Bush had said Saturday he saw no mediating role for the Soviets, one official said Sunday that Bush would welcome any influence they may have in getting Iraq to pull out of Kuwait. An administration official said Sunday that any discussion of Soviet mediation implies that the gulf crisis is a dispute between Iraq and the United States. The administration says that U.S. forces are in the area to enforce an international response to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and threat against Saudi Arabia. The officials would speak only on condition of anonymity. The administration on Sunday began working out the details of the Helsinki meeting. ``Everybody's scrambling to put their pieces together,'' said one official. Bush returns to Washington on Monday evening from his three-week vacation. Sig Rogich, the White House official in charge of advance logistics and imagemaking, was called back from a vacation Sunday to coordinate such details as where in Helsinki the meeting will be held and what time. Sununu flew Saturday to his home state of New Hampshire after arriving Saturday in Washington from London, and on Sunday was driving his family back to Washington. He did not plan to see Bush until the president's return to the capital. Lower-level staffers met at the White House on Sunday to begin work on logistics and contacting their Soviet counterparts. Bush held his proposal for a summit meeting so closely to his vest that several top White House staff members did not know about it when they were in the Soviet Union during the week, officials said. Bush's secretary of state, James A. Baker III, made the arrangements by phone with his Soviet counterpart. Chief of Staff John Sununu last week led a White House team to the Soviet Union at Moscow's invitation to explain the technical workings of the U.S. executive branch. Sununu knew before he left that Bush had proposed a summit meeting and was kept abreast of developments but did not play a key role in arranging the summit, aides said. While ongoing conventional arms talks will be on the agenda, that portion of the meeting ``would just be a review,'' of the negotiations between the two countries, said an official. The United States and Soviet Union are engaged in talks to reduce troops and tanks in Europe and hope to get an agreement in time for a 35-nation conference that is planned in Europe in November. Bush and Gorbachev also will discuss regional issues, such as the ongoing conflict in Cambodia and Soviet involvement in Afghanistan, according to the president and his aides, Bush's wife, Barbara, and Gorbachev's wife Raisa also will travel to Helsinki. No details of their schedule have been disclosed.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaitis Say Iraq Took $1 Billion in Gold, 15 Aircraft
DOC.TEXT: Iraq seized 15 Kuwait Airways planes and $1 billion in gold from the Central Bank when it invaded its oil-rich neighbor, Kuwaiti leaders said in interviews published Sunday. The allegations appeared in the weekly Observer newspaper, which interviewed several exiled Kuwaiti leaders in Saudi Arabia. Cars, furniture, refrigerators and television sets were loaded up and taken to Baghdad, where Iraqi television described the stolen goods as ``the wealth of the emirs of Kuwait,'' The Observer said. It said that among the first objectives of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's invading troops was Kuwait's Central Bank, where employees were forced to open the safe. The Iraqis took about 365 million Kuwaiti dinars in cash, worth more than $1 billion at the time. ``But then Saddam did a strange thing. He linked the Kuwaiti dinar to the Iraqi currency, which lowered its value by several hundred percent,'' Kuwaiti Foreign Minister Sheik Sabah al-Ahmad al-Sabah was quoted as saying. The Iraqis also seized about $1 billion in gold ingots, Sabah said. After repairing the main runway at Kuwait Airport, which was damaged during the invasion, the Iraqis flew out two Boeing 767s, one Boeing 727, five Airbus 310s, three Airbus 300s, two Gulfstream G3s, and two Hawker Siddeleys _ all belonging to Kuwait Airways, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Photographer: Embassy Personnel Burning Furniture, Drinking Pool Water
With AM-Gulf-Americans Home, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Americans remaining in the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait are breaking up the furniture for firewood and boiling water from the swimming pool to drink, a photographer who accompanied Jesse Jackson to the Middle East said Sunday. D. Michael Cheers, a freelance photo journalist who also has worked as a consultant to Jackson, said the streets of Kuwait City outside the embassy are ``basically deserted'' but are heavily patrolled by Iraqi troops who invaded the country on Aug. 2. Cheers said he heard no shots fired in the streets, although Bonnie Anderton, a Denver woman who was among the hostages returning with Jackson, said the sound of gunfire was frequent. Noting that Iraqi officials had described American and other foreign hostages as guests, Mrs. Anderton said, ``It is the only hotel I have ever been a guest in that I don't intend to leave a tip.'' ``We were sleeping on the floor, there was no water and no power and we were being eaten alive by bugs,'' she said. Mrs. Anderton and Lloyd Sutherland, 76, of El Paso, Texas, both told of eating a diet heavy on frozen turkey. ``I have never eaten so much turkey in my life,'' said Sutherland. Cheers said Edward Johnson, 62, a St. Louis businessman who took refuge in the embassy while in Kuwait City, told him that much of the frozen food later spoiled. The embassy was without outside power and was operating its generators only part of the time to conserve them. He said the hostages had switched to a diet of canned goods, especially tuna. ``They are boiling water from the pool and breaking up furniture from the compound to use to cook in the wood stoves,'' said the photographer, who took pictures inside the embassy compound for The Associated Press. Outside, he said, ``The streets, as well as the highways, are just littered with burned out cars and cars that have been abandoned, the tires taken off of them.'' ``We went to this beach-front not far from the embassy compound, and it was just littered with spent shells,'' he said. ``The place is pretty messed up,'' he said. The streets were virtually deserted both on their first visit on Friday, a Moslem holy day, and when they visited again on Saturday, Cheers added. The photographer said the scene in Baghdad, the capital of Iraq, was a sharp contrast to that in Kuwait City. ``You don't see the tanks in the street and the sandbags,'' he said. ``People are going about their ordinary business.'' Jackson flew to Amman, Jordan, on Monday, went on to Baghdad on Wednesday and flew to Kuwait on Friday. On that trip, he went to the Embassy but did not get past the entrance. After flying to Baghdad again and meeting with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, Jackson returned to Kuwait to pick up the hostages. On the trip across the Atlantic in the Iraqi airways jumbo jet, the hostages had little to say, Cheers reported. ``Their attitude was, `We are just stressed out. We have been told so many different things at so many different times over the course of the last month.' Basically, they just wanted to be left alone.'' When they arrived at Washington-Dulles International Airport, few of the hostages chose to talk with reporters. Most simply went their ways to hotels or to catch flights home.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany's Trade Fair Gets Capitalist Makeover
DOC.TEXT: A former showcase for sleepy state-run enterprises opened Sunday as an extravaganza of capitalism. This year's Leipzig International Trade Fair is dominated by businesses from West Germany and other Western countries displaying everything from cars to computers to chemical products. East Germany's former government-owned ventures, many struggling to compete in the free-market economy that took effect July 1, also used the fair as the debut for new lines. With the influx of Western businesses, the number of exhibitors more than tripled from last year, from 1,500 to 4,600, fair organizers said. Police estimated 350,000 people traveled to Leipzig, a decaying industrial city about 100 miles southwest of Berlin. The crowds created huge traffic snarls. ``The tourist buses from East Europe don't want to come so much anymore, but the increase has been mostly in cars from West Germany and Western Europe,'' said police spokesman Peter Heimann. East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere spoke with exhibitors from other nations for about two hours, urging them to invest in East Germany and form cooperative agreements with the nation's industries. East Germany is scheduled to merge with its western neighbor Oct. 3. ``Many enterprises see new horizons at this festival,'' de Maiziere said. Gerhard Wolf, regional chief of BASF AG, a West German chemical and plastics company, told de Maiziere his company was willing to buy an East German chemical company in Schwarzheide for $66 million. Wolf said the West German company would guarantee a profitable operation. De Maiziere said he was interested in further talks. Economists predict up to 3 million of East Germany's 8 million workers could lose their jobs in the unification process.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis Splits PLO Factions
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Radical Palestinian leader George Habash has split with his long-time Syrian backers and is now in Iraq, marking a major shift within the PLO triggered by the Persian Gulf crisis, informed sources reported Sunday. They also reported that another radical, Nayef Hawatmeh, is struggling to retain control of his group, the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, after a mutiny sparked by his support for Syria's anti-Iraq stand in the month-old crisis. The developments underlined the rift within the Palestine Liberation Organization caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2. PLO chief Yasser Arafat's support for Saddam, qualified by a condemnation of the occupation of the gulf kingdom, has alienated the organization from the Arab mainstream that has opposed Saddam's action. That has cut Arafat off from the financial support of Saudi Arabia and other pro-Western gulf states, while at the same time firing up the PLO's radicals, like Habash and Hawatmeh. They reluctantly went along with Arafat's 1988 peace initiative, in which he renounced terrorism and recognized Israel. They have long argued that only military struggle will achieve a Palestinian homeland. Saddam has demanded an end to the Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip in any settlement of the gulf crisis. Habash, 64, heads the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, the second biggest faction in the PLO after Arafat's Fatah movement. His new alliance with Saddam marks an increasing tilt by PLO radicals toward Baghdad amid growing fears that Palestinian militants and other Arab groups will launch terrorist attacks on U.S., Western and Arab targets to support Iraq. Hawatmeh, 54, has said that he cannot back the Iraqis, who he says have done to Kuwait what the Israelis did to Palestine. But the Democratic Front's deputy secretary-general, Yasser Abed-Rabbo, flew to Baghdad with Arafat last week, cementing the split from Hawatmeh's leadership. Saddam already harbors the radical Palestine Liberation Front, a PLO faction led by Mohammed Abbas, known as Abul Abbas. That group hijacked the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro in 1985 and was behind an abortive seaborne raid on Israel last May. That operation led President Bush to suspend an 18-month dialogue with the PLO. The official Iraqi News Agency said in a terse dispatch that Saddam met with Habash Sunday on the crisis. The agency made no mention of Habash's old feud with Iraq over his alliance with Syrian President Hafez Assad, Saddam's Arab archrival. The Popular Front gained notoriety in the early 1970s with a series of airliner hijackings that dramatically focused world attention on the Palestinian struggle. The informed sources, speaking on condition of anonymity by telephone from Iraq, Jordan and Tunisia, said Habash flew to Baghdad Saturday on his first visit to Iraq in 14 years. They gave no more details.

DOC.HEAD: Tranquil Beach Baptism Contrasts With Chaos A Year Ago
DOC.TEXT: The day before Labor Day 1989, this resort strip was littered with broken bottles and bricks after clashes between police and thousands of youths. Sunday morning, a beachfront stage was erected and 150 people _ some clad in their Sunday best, others in shorts and sandals _ gathered for an Atlantic Ocean baptism. ``I am obviously finding that this is a much more enjoyable situation than a year ago,'' said City Manager Aubrey Watts. While some have complained about an excessive buildup of police for this year's Laborfest, the police presence and a smaller holiday crowd than last year clearly were having the affect of preventing violence. The looting and clashes last year resulted in 158 arrests, 43 injuries, $1.4 million in damage to stores and lingering accusations of racism and police brutality. At Sunday's service, which ended with a dozen baptisms in the Atlantic Ocean, the worshippers clapped and raised their hands singing ``The Lord God is holy.'' ``We're taking Jesus Christ out of the church, out of the four walls of the church and into the streets and cities where people live,'' said the Rev. Wellington Boone, president and founder of New Generation Campus Ministries. Students from predominantly black East Coast colleges made up much of the crowd for the annual fraternity festival, and most of them were not here to seek religious deliverance. Still, the Sunday baptism represented a sharp change in tone from last year's festival, attended by more than 100,000 people$. Police estimated the crowd this year at about 28,000 people. Spokesman Lew Thurston said 48 people had been charged with misdemeanor offenses along the oceanfront as of 6 a.m. Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Southwest, South and Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms and showers hit the Southwest, South and portions of the Midwest on Sunday. Hot weather prevailed in the nation's midsection. Morning rainfall included 2{ inches at Sunset Crater, Ariz., and 1.3 inches in Flagstaff. Heavy rain caused caused flooding at New Orleans and high winds damaged a boat at Laplace., La. Afternoon showers and thunderstorms extended over Florida, southwest Georgia, Alabama, southern Mississippi, southern Louisiana, southern Texas, northern Arizona, southern Wyoming, western South Dakota, Iowa, south-central Minnesota, northwest Illinois, eastern and south-central Ohio, north-central Pennsylvania, New York and northern New England. The low temperature for the nation Sunday was 30 degrees at Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 61 degrees at San Simeon, Calif., to 101 degrees at Yuma, Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: Long-Sought Forward Headquarters Achieved in Crisis
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has done what pressure, persuasion and countless cups of Arabic coffee among diplomats could not _ given the United States a military headquarters in the Middle East. Set up during the past week in a suite of borrowed offices at a Saudi government building, U.S. Central Command forward is now the main nerve center for Operation Desert Shield. From his new post, Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf oversees the growing American force dispatched to deter Saddam and his formidable Iraqi military units from invading Saudi Arabia. If war comes, it will be from the center _ and a communications center at an undisclosed location _ that Schwarzkopf and his officers will run the battle. Capt. Ronald Wildermuth, Central Command's chief of information, said about half the command's staff of 700 officers and enlisted personnel have been brought to Saudi Arabia from the headquarters at MacDill Air Force Base near Tampa, Fla. Some Riyadh hotels, filled with the new personnel, have become minor fortresses, with concrete anti-terrorist barricades blocking driveways and airport-type security checks for visitors. Americans, wearing brown-and-tan desert camouflage, mingle with white-robed Arabs in lobbies and coffee shops. The command, responsible for U.S. military operations in 19 nations in the Mideast and southwest Asia, has been based in Florida since 1983 because no Arab nation was willing to act as host. Suggestions that this may be changed by Desert Shield are adamantly rejected by both senior U.S. and Saudi officials. ``Centcom forward,'' they say, is temporary and will disappear once the gulf crisis is over. ``We have made it very clear that we have no intention of establishing permanent bases in Saudi Arabia,'' said Schwarzkopf. U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, who helped convince Saudi King Fahd of the need for American help following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, quoted the Saudi monarch as saying he trusted the United States to fulfill its commitment and leave if asked. The value of a forward headquarters and supply base has been obvious to U.S. leaders since Central Command was established as a spinoff from the Carter Administration's ``rapid deployment force.'' In the absence of ground-based facilities in the gulf, the United States has depended on long-range airlift and the pre-positioning of material at Diego Garcia, a base in the Indian Ocean, about 2,500 miles away. Except for Oman, which allowed the Navy refueling privileges and an airstrip for a reconnaissance plane during the Iran-Iraq war, the nearest thing to a permanent U.S. base in the region is at Bahrain, where a small naval squadron, the Middle East Force, has been stationed since 1949. Bahrain provides dock space for the force's flagship, USS La Salle, and the use of a small shore facility. The American profile is so low, however, that uniforms are never worn on shore and U.S. diplomats caution newcomers not to offend the Bahrainis by referring to the facilities as a ``base.'' In 1988, reports circulated that the long-desired forward base had found a host country. Bahrain has since been named as the country, but the deal fell through after the Iran-Iraq war came to a close last year. Most U.S. officers won't comment when asked whether the current crisis could lead to a permanent presence, with American forces staying on to protect the Saudi oil fields. A U.S. officer, who asked not to be identifed, said he believed Desert Shield ``might help to convince the Arabs that having us around isn't such a bad thing.'' ``If that should happen,'' he said, ``we will owe it all to Saddam Hussein.''

DOC.HEAD: Quake Shakes Ecuador, Causes Damage
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake and aftershocks rattled this capital and several cities on the Pacific coast early Sunday, causing minor damage to some homes. No injuries were reported. The quake registered 5.4 on the Richter scale, the Geodesic Institute of Quito reported. Its epicenter was 37 miles northeast of Bahia de Caraquez, a Pacific coast city 134 miles west of Quito. The earthquake struck around midnight Saturday, and several aftershocks followed, the Institute said. Local radio stations said the walls of some old houses suffered slight damage, but there were no reported injuries. A temblor registering 4.4 on the Richter scale was felt at 10:50 a.m. Sunday in Quito, but there were no reports of damage or injuries. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets, Americans Head For Mountain Range to Set Caving Record
DOC.TEXT: In a true test of international diplomacy, a team of Soviets and Americans will try to break a world record by spending 20 days in the dark without showering while wearing rubber suits. It's not a stunt for ``Ripley's Believe It Or Not.'' The 10-man international team is headed to the Caucasus Mountains in the Soviet Republic of Georgia to best the world's caving depth record, currently just under a mile. ``It is our little way of international peace through caving,'' said John Sheltens, president of the National Speleological Society. Speleology is the scientific study and examination of caves. The group, based in Huntsville, Ala., sent four of its members from Illinois, Tennessee and Alabama to the southwestern tip of the Soviet Union on Friday for the expedition, which they hope to begin by the end of this week. The Americans and six Soviets want to descend one mile _ 5,280 feet. That would beat the record set at a cave near Grenoble, France, where explorers descended 5,250 feet. To beat the depth record, the team will actually have to climb. A 10-mile hike up the mountains in the republic of Georgia will bring them to the entrance of the Sneznaya Cave, 7,500 feet above sea level. A separate 10-man team will be stationed at the mouth of the cave while the cavers spend nearly three weeks surrounded by rock walls. Another crew made an advance descent into the cave to set up provisions at two campsites. After reaching the top of the glacier-like mountain, the cave dwellers will don dry suits, special rubber clothes to protect against wetness. Then the descent begins. ``The first 2,000 feet of descent is mostly vertical _ a series of pits that we'll have to do on rope,'' said John Moses, a chemist from the Chicago suburb of Glen Ellyn who is leading the expedition. ``Then what happens is that part of the cave intersects a major river passage. We're hoping the dry suits float.'' The team will follow the river, floating in it if necessary, to a depth of at least one mile below the surface. The cold and damp will likely be the most bothersome, but there are mental challenges as well, Moses said. ``We're going to be climbing into a soggy sleeping bag, and when you are out of touch with daylight you tend to crave a taste of color,'' Moses said Another problem could be communicating. ``Language is always a stumbling block,'' said Sheltens, who explored with the Soviets during the society's first trip to their country. ``But when you're with people that are doing the same thing that you are doing, you work things out.'' The trip is the second the caving society has made to the Soviet Union in two years. The society is currently the host of a group of Soviets on a multi-state caving excursion, the second tour of its kind, Sheltens said. ``What we are finding out is that we are much more alike than we are different,'' Sheltens. said in a telephone interview from his home in Hot Springs, S.D.

DOC.HEAD: Libya, Sudan Sign Plan for Integration
DOC.TEXT: Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi and Sudanese strongman Lt. Gen. Omar Hassan el-Bashir have signed an agreement to integrate their North African countries, the official Libyan news agency reported Sunday. The agreement was signed Saturday night in Tripoli, the Libyan capital, said the JANA news agency. The brief dispatch, monitored in Rome, did not elaborate on the scope of the plan. But el-Bashir said in March the proposed plan would involve cooperation in political, cultural, economic and security fields. Libya has been one of Sudan's main suppliers of military weapons used to fight a civil war in the south. Since taking power in a military coup last year, el-Bashir has dismantled parliament and instituted Libyan-style ``people's committees'' intended to discuss and vote on government policy. The two nations share a 200-mile border. In the 21 years since he seized power, Gadhafi has tried and failed to forge various mergers with many North African nations.

DOC.HEAD: Soldier Father Charged With Misdemeanor Child Abuse
DOC.TEXT: A soldier accused of leaving his three children by themselves when he was deployed to the Middle East has been charged with misdemeanor child abuse, police said. Staff Sgt. Faagalo Savaiki's two boys, aged 13 and 9, and their 12-year-old sister were found dirty and alone Wednesday at their home, police said. They were without food, and pets in the home were hungry. Savaiki, a soldier with the 501st Signal Battalion based at nearby Fort Campbell, Ky., had been sent to Saudi Arabia the week before. ``To me, it's just blatant neglect of the children,'' said Clarksville police Sgt. Bill Poor, who is in charge of the civil investigation. Savaiki was charged Friday with three counts of child abuse, one for each of the children, Poor said. ``There may be other charges filed,'' Poor said Saturday. The warrants will not be served until Savaiki returns from Saudi Arabia, he said. On Thursday, Savaiki flew from Saudi Arabia to American Samoa after learning his mother was gravely ill. Poor said the children's mother, Joyce Savaiki, has been told of their plight, but cannot afford to buy a plane ticket from Hawaii to Clarksville. The mother has been living in Hawaii with her family since separating from her husband more than a month ago. ``I do not know why she did not take custody of the children after the separation,'' said Poor, who said the case remains under investigation. A neighbor, David Kimberling, said he feels certain there are mitigating circumstances. ``It will be interesting to hear his side of the story,'' he said. Fort Campbell spokesman Bill Harralson said last week that Savaiki's unit had no record of him being divorced or separated from his wife. Single parents' units must have information on file on who will be responsible for taking care of their children or their home if they are deployed, said Harralson. The children were placed in a foster home Friday, and will remain in the custody of the Tennessee Department of Human Services until the courts decide who should take care of them. The children had continued to attend school for several days after their father was deployed. A member of Savaiki's unit who checked on the children Wednesday notified authorities. ``There is no way those kids should be in the house without parental supervision after dark,'' Poor said. ``What if a burglar broke in or a fire started?''

DOC.HEAD: Romer Writes Apology to Eagle Scouts
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Roy Romer sent a handwritten apology to two New Jersey boy scouts who heard the governor lose his temper on a talk radio show last week when he was criticized for not congratulating them. ``I am writing to you personally so that you may understand my attitude and feelings about your personal achievement of becoming Eagle Scouts and about the way my office handled the issue,'' Romer said in the letter Friday to Douglas Baker Jr., 14, and Derek Edmund, 17, of Oradell, N.J. ``I honor them highly, and it's unfortunate that we got this confused with my views of the techniques of talk radio,'' Romer said Saturday. ``I certainly regret any anger that got out.'' Romer cut loose with a 20-minute tirade on station KOA on Wednesday when he was criticized for refusing to send a letter of commendation to the two Boy Scouts. Talk show host George Weber invited the public to write letters addressed to ``Stingy Roy.'' Romer said his office did not generally send letters of commendation to citizens of other states.

DOC.HEAD: Subway Riders Find Pennies To Be Useful Weapons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sydnye is cq in 3rd graf.
DOC.TEXT: New Yorkers are giving their 2 cents worth to the city's subway system _ nearly 1 million pennies a week, in fact, to purchase ride tokens. Clerks and Transit Authority officials say some people are flooding token booth clerks with pennies in revenge for a recent 15-cent fare hike and what they perceive as poor service. ``You can tell because they come down the stairs with a smile on their face, shaking a fist full of pennies,'' said token clerk Sydnye Thomas. ``They put the handful of pennies in the slot and turn their head and laugh.'' The pennies slow the work of the clerks. Longer lines at token booths have become common since the cost of a token rose in January from $1 to $1.15. The Transit Authority, which operates the subways, is getting so many pennies that it is now the largest depositor of pennies with the Federal Reserve, The New York Times reported Sunday. The number of pennies received by token clerks increased from 300,000 a week to about 950,000 a week after the January price boost. Signs at token booths read, ``No pennies,'' but the signs add, ``Please,'' because pennies are legal currency and cannot be refused.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Would Rather Eat Mud Than Capitulate, Official Says
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government Sunday acknowleged it was rationing food but said Iraqis would rather eat mud than bow to a foreign power. Government spokesman Naji Al-Hadithi denied reports that the U.N. embargo on Iraq caused shortages but said the government was instituting steps to reduce food consumption. ``We have a war-tested society. We have a war-tested economy. So even if we eat mud, we will resist pressure and not kneel down to any foreign power,'' he said. Last week, sources inside Iraq said rationing was to begin Sept. 1, and foreigners who left the country reported lines for bread and other food. The U.N. embargo enforced by a flotilla of U.S. and other warships has halted nearly all of Iraq's vital oil exports and food imports, aiming to force an Iraqi pullout from Kuwait. Al-Hadithi and Information and Culture Minister Latif Nasaif Jasim took a defiant stance in a meeting with reporters Sunday, saying Iraq wanted peace, but was prepared for war. Jasim claimed Iraq, which fought an eight-year war with Iran, was not afraid of war with the United States, which deployed tens of thousands of troops in the Saudi desert after Iraq invaded Kuwait a month ago. He said his country had 1.5 million men under arms and 5.5 million volunteers ready to fight. ``During the war with Iran, hundreds of American-made planes darkened our skies, and even our children used to throw rocks at these planes,'' Jasim said. ``So if Bush wants to stay in power, he will pull out his soldiers and not make war.'' ``We need only bread and water. We need no more than that. We can live for a long time,'' said Jasim. ``Dignity is more important than food.'' Under a plan organized by the ruling Ba'ath Party, stores will limit the quantity of certain products that can be sold at one time, al-Hadithi said. ``If you need one kilogram (2.2 pounds) of rice, you will be allowed two but not 10. In the past, you could get 20,'' he said. The plan, he said, is a precaution prompted by the U.N. sanctions but not a response to any spot shortages. ``We are determined to live on our own cultivation,'' said Al-Hadithi. ``Iraq reached self-sufficiency in vegetables and fruit during the war with Iran.'' He said production of rice and wheat were up significantly, and that the government had taken steps to encourage farmers to put more land into cultivation. Two food store owners in Baghdad, Iraq's capital, said they had been told the rationing plan would limit purchases of such items as rice, sugar, tea, cooking oil, baby food, detergent and soap. ``We really don't think about this. I'm not hoarding. Everything is here. We are not worried about it,'' said one shopper, who declined to give her name.

DOC.NOTE: For Release 8 p.m. EDT, TIME set by source.
DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Accuses Khmer Rouge of Massacre in Train Attacks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Kompong Chhnang is cq. Monday is also cq in lead.
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International on Monday accused communist guerrillas of massacring more than 50 people in two train attacks in central Cambodia. In a statement, the international human rights group urged the Cambodian guerrilla coalition, which includes the communist Khmer Rouge, to ensure that those involved in the killings ``are removed from their positions and brought to justice.'' Amnesty International said the victims apparently were singled out because they were employees of the Vietnamese-installed government in Phnom Penh. ``At least 26 people were rounded up and shot dead when a train was ambushed and stopped in Kompong Trach on July 1, and at least 30 others died in a similar incident in Kompong Chhnang on July 15,'' the statement said. At Amnesty International's London headquarters, an official said the information came from sources who have been in contact with people in Cambodia. He said the sources could not be identified. In previous reports, Western journalists have quoted injured survivors at Phnom Penh hospitals as saying the guerrillas killed several civilians in the July 15 attack. The survivors said land mines crippled the train before the Khmer Rouge struck with grenade launchers and machine guns. At the time, the Khmer Rouge radio said the guerrillas killed 15 soldiers and wounded 15 others but made no mention of civilian casualities. The Cambodian government's official SPK news agency reported on July 16 that robbers had killed more than 100 passengers and taken their property in an attack on a train in Kompong Trach. The news agency said Gen. Tea Banh, the defense minister, mentioned the raid while speaking two days earlier about the fight against the guerrillas. It was not possible to determine whether the SPK report was referring to the killings cited by Amnesty International. SPK did not specifically mention the Khmer Rouge or give the date of the attack. Some claims by the Phnom Penh government have been exaggerated. In the past, the United States and Amnesty International have also accused the Phnom Penh government of serious human rights abuses. The city of Kompong Chhnang, the capital of the province of the same name, is about 50 miles northwest of Phnom Penh. Kompong Trach is about 60 miles east of the Cambodian capital. The Khmer Rouge slaughtered hundreds of thousands of people in rural slave labor camps and execution chambers when it held power from 1975-78. Vietnam installed the current communist government after its forces invaded Phnom Penh in late 1978. The Khmer Rouge, supported by China, now is allied with two non-communist groups in the guerrilla coalition _ the U.S.-backed forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Son Sann's Khmer People's National Liberation Front.

DOC.HEAD: Former Nixon Adviser Says Saddam Offered $25 Million Bribe To Mubarak
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: A former presidential adviser said he has solid information that Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein offered Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak a $25 million bribe to try to keep Egypt neutral in the Persian Gulf crisis. ``Saddam Hussein had $25 million placed in an Egyptian bank account, for Mubarak's use,'' Rabbi Baruch Korff said in an interview published in the Providence Sunday Journal. Korff said Saddam also offered to share with Mubarak the spoils of dividing up Kuwait, which Iraq invaded Aug. 2, as well as Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf sheikdoms. Korff, a former adviser to President Nixon, has just returned from a seven-week tour of the Mideast. Korff frequently travels to the region on official and unofficial missions for the U.S. government. He said he could not divulge the source of his information or the nature of his most recent trip. Korff said others, including Sen. Frank R. Lautenberg, D-N.J., have heard Mubarak discuss the alleged bribe. Lautenberg's press secretary, Steve Schlein, said Friday that the senator met with Mubarak during a visit to Egypt 10 days ago. He said Mubarak said Saddam had attempted to bribe him, but didn't mention the amount. ``We cannot comment on this because we have no other information,'' said Mohamad Amr of the Egyptian Embassy in Washington. ```We have not been privy to discussions between the senator and President Mubarak.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Narrow Prime Suspect List to 4 in Campus Slayings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf with 2 grafs to UPDATE with police searching creek beside Humphrey's apartment complex; picks up 4th graf pvs, `An Ohio ...' SUBS 10th grav pvs, `Autopsy results ...,' to CORRECT victim's name to `Tracy,' sted `Tracey.' ADDS 3 grafs at end to UPDATE with comment from university; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Investigators narrowed their list of prime suspects to four Sunday in the grisly knife slayings of five students and hinted that the serial killer left ``messages of some importance.'' Police would not say whether 18-year-old Edward Lewis Humphrey, a part-time freshman at the University of Florida charged with assaulting his grandmother, was among the four. However, two police officers in hip waders on Sunday used a metal detector to search a creek next to the apartment complex where Humphrey lives. They did not appear to find anything, said police Cpl. Robert McDowell. Police have already picked over garbage in the complex's trash containers, but have not said whether they recovered a murder weapon. An Ohio fugitive, 58-year-old Warren Virgil Tinch, was dropped from the list, said Alachua County Sheriff's spokesman Lt. Spencer Mann. Tinch is sought in Ohio in the stabbing death of a 52-year-old woman and is suspected of stealing cars in Ocala and Gainesville a week before the killings. ``To say he's still a suspect (in the slayings) would be incorrect,'' Mann said. But he said police were not prepared to say who is on the list. A week after the first two mutilated bodies were found, police disclosed Sunday that the killer left messages or clues at the victims' apartments that could tie him to all five murders. But they refused to characterize these messages except to say they were not in the form of notes or other writings. ``The messages were given to us from the crime scenes,'' said Lt. Sadie Darnell, spokeswoman for the Gainesville Police Department. ``The messages are indirect (ones) that we're interpreting to be messages of some importance.'' Mann added that no ``calling cards'' were found on any of the bodies. ``It's not a signature-type homicide,'' Mann said. Autopsy results on Tracy Inez Paules and Manuel Taboada, both 23, showed they died of stab wounds similar to those that killed the other three, Mann said Sunday. But unlike the first three, the bodies of Miss Paules and Taboada were not mutilated. Mann declined to say whether the same weapon was used in all five slayings. Miss Paules and Taboada were found Tuesday at the apartment they shared at the same complex where Humphrey lived for a few weeks this summer. A neighbor said Humphrey was romantically interested in Miss Paules and often waited for her by the pool. Also killed were Christina Powell, 17, of Jacksonville; Sonya Larson, 18, of Deerfield Beach; and Christa Hoyt, 18, of Newberry. All five lived at off-campus apartments on the city's southwest side and all were students at either the University of Florida or Sante Fe Community College. Most of the University of Florida's 34,000 students were gone over the weekend for the Labor Day holiday. Many who stayed attended church services Sunday to mourn for the victims. ``I pray we're not so gripped by fear that we're afraid to go out and meet people,'' Drew Settimio told the congregation at Crossroads Church of Christ, which included many students. ``I pray the fear of our community will be eased.'' Humphrey, an Indialantic youth authorities have described as emotionally troubled, remained in the Brevard County Jail on Sunday pending a $1 million bond on charges of assaulting his 79-year-old grandmother. Police kept up surveillance at his Gainesville apartment and car in Indialantic but still have not sought search warrants to check them out. To do so, a judge would have to rule that there is enough evidence to show probable cause of Humphrey's involvement in the crimes. ``We're not going to do anything to jeopardize this case,'' Mann said. ``We're going to do it right. We're going to do it by the book.'' Brevard County Public Defender R.J. Russo said he was puzzled as to why no search warrants had been sought and said he planned to ask Tuesday for a reduction in Humphrey's bond. Up to 18 investigators flew Saturday and Sunday to at least nine other states to follow up on tips and leads related to the slayings, Darnell said. The states were California, New York, Oregon, Montana, Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi, Tennessee and Nevada, although Darnell would not name specific towns. University President John Lombardi said Sunday that school will continue as usual when it reopens Tuesday, except for continued escort services, increased security and extended deadlines for students to withdraw from or change classes. So far, about 100 students have decided either to transfer or sit out a semester because of the slayings, Lombardi said. ``We believe this community to be as safe as any other university community in America,'' he said. ``Would I send my child back to the University of Florida? Yes, I would.''

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Kills Four in South Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded on the main seaside highway entrance to this southern Lebanese port city Sunday, killing at least four people and injuring three, police said. The car, a black Toyota packed with 110 pounds of TNT, was parked about 15 yards from a checkpoint manned by militiamen of the pro-Syrian Amal movement when it exploded at 7:30 p.m., said a police spokesman under condition of anonymity. Two Amal militiamen and two people passing in the street were killed. Two other bystanders and one Amal irregular were wounded, police said. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the bombing. This was the seventh car bomb in Lebanon this year and the second in Tyre in a month. In all, 14 people have been killed and 106 wounded in the explosions. The deadliest car bomb was on Aug 3. Eight people were killed and 75 were injured when the bomb went off in Tyre.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sees Challenges Ahead as He Prepares for Soviet Summit
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Grafs 9-15 new to UPDATE with White House not commenting on magazine report of planned covert operation; responses from congressional leaders. SUBS grafs 15-16 pvs, bgng: `Meanwhile, Sen. Sam ...,' to conform. Pickup 17th graf pvs, bgng: ``Right now, while ...''
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Sunday ``challenging times'' lie ahead as he prepared for next weekend's summit with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and began a second month of trying to force Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait. As the president was winding up his three-week vacation in Maine, a group of four-dozen American women and children arrived in Washington aboard an Iraqi airliner after being freed from captivity, telling tales of harsh treatment and deprivation. One month after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, an estimated 11,000 Westerners remained trapped there and in Iraq, including about 3,000 Americans. ``A week from now, perhaps at this minute, I will be sitting in Helsinki, Finland, talking with President (Mikhail) Gorbachev. These are challenging times,'' Bush said at one of two church services he attended here along with the evangelist, Rev. Billy Graham. The president, who was to return to Washington on Monday evening, discussed summit preparations and recent Persian Gulf developments with his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, aides said. Bush announced the one-day meeting in Helsinki, Finland _ to be his third as president with Gorbachev _ on Saturday. And although the president said there was no set agenda, aides on Sunday said the Middle East crisis clearly would top the discussion. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush and Gorbachev would talk about the Middle East, discuss ways of speeding up negotiations on reaching an agreement on conventional force reductions in Europe this fall and go over several regional hot spots, including Afghanistan and Cambodia. Although Moscow has expressed only lukewarm support for the U.S.-led military force in the Persian Gulf region, Bush generally has been ``very pleased with the support of the Soviet Union'' on Persian Gulf policy, Fitzwater said. The White House refused to comment on a published report that Bush had approved a covert operation to overthrow Saddam. Congressional leaders said they knew nothing of the matter. Newsweek magazine, in its Sept. 3 issue, said Saudi Arabia was preparing to fund the effort by the CIA and other western intelligence agencies. The magazine said the conduit for the money will be the Saudi ambassador to the United States, Prince Bandar bin Sultan. ``I would truthfully say that I do not know now,'' said Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., who chairs the Senate Armed Services Committee, adding, ``if I did know, I wouldn't be able to tell you. ...'' But Nunn, in an interview on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press,'' said he hopes the United States will begin ``working with our friends in the (Persian Gulf) area to make his (Saddam's) position in Kuwait untenable.'' Senate Minority Leader Robert Dole of Kansas and House Majority Thomas S. Foley of Washington also said during television appearances that they knew nothing of a planned covert operation. On the CBS-TV program ``Face the Nation,'' Dole said, ``I don't have any information on that at all....'' During the same program, Foley declined ``either to confirm or deny'' the report or discuss it. In Washington, the Kuwait Embassy promised financial assistance to American families facing money problems because of Iraq's holding of hostages in Kuwait. ``We stand ready, willing and are able to share in the costs, whatever we are asked for by these families,'' Kuwaiti Ambassador Sheikh Saud Nasir al-Sabah said. After arriving Sunday at Washington-Dulles International Airport, one of the freed American hostages, Lloyd Culbertson, 76, of El Paso, Texas, said some of the Americans left behind were being held without food and water. ``If it were not for the grace of God and Jesse Jackson, we would not be here. The State Department has not lifted a hand for us,'' Culbertson said. Jackson, who helped arrange the flight, told reporters at Dulles ``Now that the military has played its role, diplomacy must work. If preconditions make talks impossible, war is inevitable.'' Jackson appealed to the Iraqi government to turn on the water and power in the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait to prevent food from spoiling in the next few days. Traveling as a television journalist, Jackson met twice last week with the Iraqi president. Meanwhile, Nunn said during his television appearance that ``the worst case for us would be a protracted ground war.'' Nunn said he would be opposed to any offensive move by U.S. troops at this time. ``Right now, while the U.S. has an advantage in the air and sea, he (Saddam) still has the advantage on the ground,'' Nunn said. Regarding next weekend's summit, Nunn said he hoped the United States and Soviet Union could reach an agreement that would help deny Saddam ``the ability to wage war of mass destruction.'' He suggested that the Soviets _ who long have been Baghdad's main arms supplier _ deny further weapons to the Iraqis. With Graham in tow, Bush made the rounds of two church services in Kennebunkport on Sunday. After introducing Graham, a longtime friend and fishing companion, at the first service at the Kennebunkport Congregational Church, Bush spoke briefly about the current Middle East crisis. ``These are very interesting times,'' he told the congregation. At the second church service, at St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Bush told worshipers: ``These are rather trying times and right know I would suggest that we get our strength from being one nation under God.''

DOC.HEAD: Two-headed Calf, World's Largest Calf Perish in Blaze
DOC.TEXT: A two-headed calf, a boar rat whose teeth would not stop growing and all 550 pounds of what proprietors declared the world's largest clam perished in a museum fire this weekend. More than 500 displays of human and animal oddities, wonders of the deep and instruments of death, the occult and superstition were destroyed Saturday in a fire at the Great American Fun House, officials said. While the calf and clam were dead long before flames engulfed the oddities museum in this town south of Orlando, charred placards in the windows note that all the exhibits had once, in fact, been ``BORN ALIVE!!!'' ``A lot of those things were one of a kind, Ripley's kind of stuff,'' said museum proprietor Vinnie Lamano at the fire scene. ``There were many things here that you'll never see again.'' Lamano and oddities collector Mark Frierson _ creator of the syndicated cartoon ``STRANGER THAN FICTION!!!'' _ opened their shrine to the bizarre inside a former surf shop 10 months ago. Arson investigators sifted through debris that included a shrunken head, the shoes of an Icelandic giant purported to be the largest man ever and some bones the museum said were used by Aborigine witch doctors to kill enemies without touching them. ``It was kind of a bizarre scene, come to think of it,'' said Kissimmee Fire Cmdr. Cleve Thomason, who estimated structural damage at between $60,000 and $120,000. The fire's cause, Thomason said, remained _ a mystery!!!

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Officials Say Saddam Must Be Destroyed
DOC.TEXT: Israeli officials said Sunday that any political solution to the Persian Gulf crisis that leaves Saddam Hussein in power means Iraq will remain a danger to world stability. Yossi Olmert, head of the Government Press Office, said it would be disastrous if President Saddam remained in power, considering his plans to develop nuclear weapons. ``Such a resolution will not be as we would like it, and it shouldn't be to the liking of the U.S. ... nor to the Arab world,'' Olmert said on Israel radio. He added that, at the least, Iraq's armed forces, which invaded oil-rich Kuwait one month ago, should be damaged to the point where Saddam's ambitions are blocked ``even if the man stays alive, at least for a period of time.'' Israel's military is on heightened alert, but officials also have said Israel has no plans to attack Iraq unless attacked first. In 1981, Israeli warplanes destroyed an Iraqi nuclear reactor believed to be developing an atomic bomb. Justice Minister Dan Meridor, who also spoke on the radio, said Saddam must not be allowed even part of his ``war spoils.'' Several other Israeli officials, including Defense Minister Moshe Arens and Air Force Commander Maj. Gen. Avihu Bin-Nun, have suggested that the gulf crisis must end with Saddam's ouster. Olmert and Meridor both said Sunday their statements were not intended as advice to President Bush, who has not said he seeks Saddam's ouster.

DOC.HEAD: One of Four Households Hit by Crimes Last Year
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 10th graf pvs, bgng, `As for households ...,' to CORRECT decrease to rise in violent crimes for caucasian households. Pickup 11th graf pvs.
DOC.TEXT: A violent crime or property crime hit one in four U.S. households last year, virtually the same level as the past five years, a Justice Department report said Sunday. ``In 1975, when this statistical series commenced, about one in three households was struck by crime,'' said Steven Dillingham, director of the Bureau of Justice Statistics which produced the report. The actual percentage of households that suffered a violent crime or property crime was 24.9 percent, up slightly from 24.6 percent in 1988, the report found. The figures include attempted as well as completed crimes. A total of 23.5 million households suffered from one of the crimes checked: rape, assault, robbery, personal theft, household theft, burglary and motor vehicle theft. The bureau's figures come from the National Crime Survey, which annually interviews members of 49,000 households nationwide to determine crimes to household members who are at least 12 years old. The NCS does not check for murder, because it compiles its information from surveys of victims. A total of 4.9 percent of households experienced a violent crime, with 3.9 percent suffering assault, 1 percent robbery and 0.1 percent rape, the survey found. The year before, violent crime had hit 4.8 percent of homes. Meanwhile, 17.8 percent of households suffered from some kind of theft, including 11.2 percent personal theft and 8.1 percent household theft; 5.1 percent suffered from a burglary; and 1.6 percent motor vehicle theft. Among the survey's findings were that like previous years, households headed by blacks, urban households and households with higher incomes suffered a higher percentage of crimes than other population segments. A total of 29.1 percent of all black households suffered from an NCS crime _ a slight increase from 29 percent in 1988. And 6.4 percent of them suffered from a violent crime, a decrease from 6.6 percent in 1988. As for households headed by Caucasians, 24.3 percent suffered from an NCS crime, up from 23.9 percent the previous year. And 4.7 percent were victimized by a violent crime, a slight rise from 4.6 in 1988. Some 25.5 percent of the households of other races combined _ Asians, Pacific Islanders and native Americans _ also suffered from an NCS crime, down from 27.4 percent in 1988. The percentage of those homes that suffered from a violent crime also decreased to 5.4 percent from 5.6 percent. A separate ethnicity category for Hispanics and non-Hispanics shows that a greater percentage of Hispanic households suffered an NCS crime last year than in 1988. Last year, 33.8 percent of households headed by Hispanics were victims of an NCS crime, up from 30 percent the previous year. Meanwhile, 7.3 percent of Hispanic households suffered a violent crime, up from 6.5 percent in 1988. Meanwhile, the percentage of urban households that have been victims of crime increased from 30.3 percent to 31.2 percent. A greater number of suburban households also were victimized _ up from 23.8 percent to 24.2 percent. At the same time, rural households experienced less crime, with only 17.2 percent suffering, compared with 18 percent in 1988. The portion of households with incomes of $15,000 and above that suffered from a crime edged downward last year, while crime hit a larger portion of households with lower incomes than it had in 1988. Still, the households with the highest target rate _ 27 percent _ were those with incomes of $25,000 or more.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Children Hurt as Fire Destroys House
DOC.TEXT: A fire Sunday swept though a house that a family had moved into the day before, injuring seven children, four of them critically, firefighters said. A man who tried to rescue the youngsters _ five siblings and their two cousins _ also was treated for smoke inhalation. The children, ranging in age from 3 to 17, were found in bedrooms and a hallway. The adults were not at home when the fire was reported Sunday morning, and crews were already battling the fire when they returned, said spokesmen for the Contra Costa Consolidated Fire District. Shames Rahmany, 3, and Habiba Rahmany, his 17-year-old sister, were in ``very critical'' condition with smoke inhalation, a hospital spokeswoman said. Two girls, 9-year-old Samea Rahmany and her cousin, Aesha Rahimi, 6, were in critical condition. Three other children were in fair condition with smoke inhalation. The fire, believed to have started in the master bedroom, gutted the house, which the Rahmany family had moved into Saturday. The cause was under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Spill From Overturned Tanker Forces Evacuation Of 300
DOC.TEXT: A tanker truck overturned and spilled hundreds of gallons of a toxic, highly combustible chemical early Sunday, forcing about 300 people out of their homes and closing an interstate highway. The 18-wheeler careened off Interstate 59 about 35 miles northeast of Birmingham around 1:30 a.m., said state Department of Public Safety spokesma Jim Hyatt. The driver, Earl Gavin, 51, of Independence, Mo., was trapped in the wreckage for nine hours, Hyatt said. He was hospitalized in Birmingham in fair condition. Authorities evacuated about 300 residents of the nearby Pinedale Shores subdivision, and opened an emergency shelter at the National Guard armory in Ashville. Traffic on I-59 was forced to detour, and the highway was not expected to reopen until late Sunday, Hyatt said. The tanker, owned by Continental Transport Express of Geismar, La., was carrying aniline, a chemical used to make dyes and photographic chemicals, Hyatt said. About 500 to 800 gallons leaked from the truck, which was carrying 3,500 to 5,000 gallons, he said. The chemical is irritating to the skin and lungs and is highly flammable, Hyatt said. About two dozen firefighters from several communities experienced some skin irritation during the cleanup, which was completed Sunday afternoon, Hyatt said. The evacuees were expected to be allowed to return home Sunday evening.

DOC.HEAD: Universityi President Stresses Business as Usual
With AM-Gainesville Slayings
DOC.TEXT: Despite lingering fear over the murders of five students, the University of Florida will be back in business Tuesday when students return from the Labor Day holiday, the school's president said Sunday. ``The University of Florida will be in full operation this week,'' John Lombardi said. As of Sunday only about 100 of the university's 34,000 students had decided to drop out for the semester or transfer because of the unsolved slayings, Lombardi said. ``We believe this community to be as safe as any other university community in America,'' he said. ``Would I sent my child back to the University of Florida? Yes, I would.'' University officials said security would continue at a heightened level on campus, including night escort services and sleeping arrangements for students afraid to stay alone at night. Academic work missed by students last week can be made up, and deadlines to drop or add classes will be extended to Friday, Lombardi said. Financial aid recipients who leave school won't lose their aid for the next semester, he added. ``We have made a commitment that nobody is to be penalized,'' he said. Student body President Michael Browne said most of his classmates remain fearful over the killings, particularly since no arrest has been made. ``I'm afraid every night. Not because of the actions of one person but because my sense of innocence, my sense of personal security has been invaded,'' Browne said. But like Lombardi, he urged students to return when classes resume. ``Above all, we must not be held hostage to our fears,'' he said. ``Giving up now will not solve anything.'' Four of the victims were students at the university; the fifth studied at Santa Fe Community College. Police said Sunday they now have four prime suspects in the case.

DOC.HEAD: 20 Albanians Flee to Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: Twenty Albanians, mostly young people, have crossed illegally into Yugoslavia, the national news agency Tanjug reported Sunday. They defected near the Yugoslav town of Plav, the report said. It did not give the date of their crossing or further details. Tanjug said about 50 Albanians illegally crossed into Yugoslavia in July. The crossings were mostly made in small groups at night. The refugees cited hard life and inability to support their families as the main reasons for their escape, the report added. More than 4,000 Albanians who fled into Western embassies in Tirana, the Albanian capital, earlier this summer were allowed to leave for the West. But authorities have since put up a wall around the embassy district. Albania is the last hard-line Communist nation in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Some Hostages Return Home, One Says He Nearly Starved
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 22nd graf pvs, bgng: `One of the passengers ...,' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with name of woman taken to hospital. Pickup 23rd graf pvs. Anderton is cq
DOC.TEXT: Four-dozen Americans reclaimed their freedom Sunday, liberated from Saddam Hussein's clutches and grateful to be back home. ``I wasn't a guest,'' said Lloyd Culbertson. ``I damned near starved to death.'' The 47 Americans, weary from 24 hours of travel and their weeks as unofficial prisoners of war, arrived at Washington-Dulles International Airport aboard an Iraqi jetliner cleared to land only for this homecoming flight. Just a handful of the passengers talked with reporters; most cleared customs and left the airport quietly with relatives. A U.S. official said 24 women, 11 men and 12 children arrived but declined to identify them, citing privacy laws. The Americans who were held in Kuwait, which was overrun by Iraqi soldiers on Aug. 2, brought ominous word that Saddam Hussein's forces may be mistreating Americans left behind. Culbertson, 76, of El Paso, Texas, said some of the hostages were being held without food and without water. He did not provide details. Culbertson took issue with Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed Sadiq al-Mashat's insistence that hostages were treated well as ``guests'' of Saddam: ``The ambassador from Iraq is dead wrong.'' ``If it were not for the grace of God and Jesse Jackson, we would not be here. The State Department has not lifted a hand for us,'' said Culbertson, who told reporters he has taught electronics to the Kuwaiti military for 5{ years. Jackson, on a trip to Baghdad, helped arrange freedom for some of the hostages. The Iraqi Airlines Boeing 747 was one of three jetliners to leave Baghdad Airport on Saturday. The flights carried hundreds of foreign women and children who left their husbands and fathers behind. A photographer who accompanied Jackson, D. Michael Cheers, said about eight of the women in the group arriving here were pregnant. Cheers said the men who were brought along were chosen because of medical problems. Cheers said those trapped at the embassy burned furniture as firewood and boiled water from the swimming pool for drinking. Culbertson described meals as ``pretty skimpy rations'' _ mainly frozen turkey. ``I have never eaten so much turkey in my life.'' Asked if the people left behind feared for their lives, Culbertson said, ``Yes, they certainly do.'' Bonnie Anderton left her husband, Richard, after an emotional parting in Kuwait. She said they talked about sending their 10-year-old daughter, Jennifer, home alone but decided against it because Mrs. Anderton needs medical treatment. She declined to say what the treatment was. She said the Americans slept on the floor, had no water or power, and Iraqi troops often fired shots nearby the U.S. Embassy compound during the day. Anderton said her family had been in Kuwait for three months, the final weeks in turmoil after Iraqi soldiers stormed the kingdom. Her husband was working as an engineer. ``I think Jennifer will agree with me: Next summer we are going to Disneyland,'' she said. Ed Johnson, a businessman from St. Louis, said he sought refuge in the embassy Aug. 17 at the suggestion of diplomats there. Johnson, who waved an American flag as he arrived, said he phoned his wife, ``and she cried and I cried.'' The situation for Americans in Baghdad was slightly better, said Beth Krekelel of St. Louis, who was taken to a hotel in the Iraqi capital and then to the U.S. Embassy there. ``I have had an enjoyable time. I have had a cross-cultural experience,'' said Krekelel, who was teaching English in Iraq. Relatives greeted the tired travelers, who made their way through customs at Dulles, which is located in a Virginia suburb of Washington. A State Department official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said there were no plans to debrief the Americans, and ``they're free to go home.'' ``From what we've seen, they don't seem to be in particularly difficult shape.
