They've obviously been through a long flight, a big ordeal,'' the spokesman said. One of the arriving passengers, a woman, was put on an ambulance and taken to a local hospital. A Texarkana, Texas, newspaper identified her as Odessa Higgins of Texarkana. The Texarkana Gazette quoted sources as saying the woman had suffered a broken hip during an auto accident while she and her husband, Bobby Higgins, were traveling in a convoy trying to reach the Jordanian border. Attempts to reach family members Sunday night were unsuccessful. Jackson, following two meetings with Iraq's president last week, arranged for more than 100 foreigners to leave Baghdad on Saturday. He told reporters the Iraqis fear a U.S. military strike. ``Now that the military has played its role, diplomacy must work. If preconditions make talks impossible, war is inevitable,'' Jackson said. al-Mashat, the Iraqi ambassador, was among those greeting the ex-hostages. He said he was there to check on the Iraqi flight crew, and to make sure the Americans were comfortable.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Of Women, Children Freed; East German Ambassador Taken To Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Western women and children held hostage by Iraq, including some who served as human shields to deter any U.S. attack, arrived back home Sunday after flights from Iraq. But the departure of several hundred more Western women and children from Baghdad was apparently delayed as Iraq withheld landing clearance for special flights from Britain and France. In addition, thousands of other hostages, including husbands and fathers of those allowed to leave, remained trapped in Iraq and occupied Kuwait with no immediate prospect of leaving. East Germany's ambassador in Kuwait was said to have been taken forcibly to Iraq after leaving his compound, which has been besieged by Iraqi troops along with the U.S. and other embassies. The East Berlin government was negotiating with Iraq for the release of Ambassador Kurt Merkel, 56, a government spokesman said on condition of anonymity. Also Sunday, about 12,000 mostly Arab and Asian refugees streamed from Iraq into Jordan, where tens of thousands of impoverished evacuees already languish in refugee camps. Thousands were trying to cross into Turkey and Iran. Totals provided by various airlines and diplomats indicated that nearly 700 Westerners and Japanese were allowed to leave Iraq over the weekend. In all, about 21,000 Westerners, including 3,000 Americans, were trapped in Iraq and Kuwait by the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of its oil-rich neighbor. In London, a spokesman for Virgin Atlantic Airways said the airline had been planning a special flight to Baghdad on Monday after hearing from British diplomatic sources that about 200 more Western women and children, including some Americans, would be ready to leave. But the spokesman said the airline received a telex Sunday afternoon from Iraqi civil aviation authorities revoking landing clearance. In Paris, the French Foreign Ministry said Iraqi authorities so far have not granted landing permission for an Air France Airbus that has been on standby at Le Bourget airport north of Paris. The plane had been scheduled to fly to Baghdad on Monday morning to pick up Western hostages, the French news agency AFP said. French news reports said the delay was caused by bickering over the timing of the flight, with the Iraqis insisting that the plane not arrive at night or in the early morning. British and French officials said they had asked their embassies in Baghdad to continue pressing the Iraqis to allow the flights to land. If that is not possible, a British Foreign Office spokesman said hostages could return home on Iraqi Airways, even though regularly scheduled flights by the Iraqi carrier are banned under the U.N. trade embargo. A chartered Iraqi Airways Boeing 747 that left Baghdad with more than 300 Westerners, including 47 Americans, arrived outside Washington on Sunday after stopovers in Paris and London to disembark passengers. Civil rights leader Jesse Jackson helped arrange the flight during his trip to Iraq and Kuwait, and he was aboard the plane that flew to Washington. The son of one of the hostages who landed in London said passengers spent at least four hours on the Iraqi plane, waiting in scorching temperatures for Jackson to return from Kuwait with some Americans before it could take off. Nadeem Faheem told Sky Television in Britain: ``There was no air-conditioning on the plane ... it was absolutely disgusting.'' Among those arriving in Britain was Stuart Lockwood, the 5-year-old British boy whose hair was tousled by Saddam in a television encounter with a group of Western hostages last month. The jet that arrived in Washington was one of three to leave Baghdad airport on Saturday. The flights carried hundreds of women and children and ailing men. On Sunday morning, a West German jet carrying 311 women and children from 22 countries arrived in Frankfurt on a flight from Baghdad. The West German Foreign Ministry said 250 women and 61 children were aboard the Lufthansa Airbus, including 71 Germans and 60 Americans. Salem Saba, a U.S. citizen from Chicago who was on the plane, left Baghdad with his wife and five small children. He said conditions had deteriorated in the Iraqi capital. ``You get coupons for sugar and for bread,'' he said. Later Sunday, 68 Japanese women and children returned to Tokyo on a flight from Baghdad. Twelve other Japanese women and children, dependents of diplomats at Japan's Embassy in Baghdad, arrived in Jordan on Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Political Briefs
DOC.TEXT: Two independent polls released Sunday showed former Sen. Lawton Chiles with a comfortable lead over ex-congressman Bill Nelson going into Tuesday's Democratic primary for governor of Florida. Both polls had Chiles virtually even in polls with Republican Gov. Bob Martinez. The Florida Opinion Poll, published by The New York Times Florida newspapers, showed Chiles with 44 percent of the Democratic voters to 32 percent for Nelson, a six-term congressman. Twenty-four percent were undecided. The poll was conducted through random telephone interviews of 842 registered voters Aug. 25-29. Its margin of error was 4 percent. The Florida Newspaper Poll published Sunday gave Chiles a 55-30 margin over Nelson, with only 15 percent undecided. That poll, for the Sun-Sentinel of Fort Lauderdale, The Orlando Sentinel and The Florida Times-Union, interviewed 750 registered voters Aug. 25-27, and had a margin of error of 4 points. Sunday's polls gave Martinez landslide margins over his nearest GOP competitor, state Sen. Marlene Woodson Howard, and also put him nearly even in a match-up with Chiles. The Florida Newspaper Poll gave Chiles a 45-40 lead over Martinez. The New York Times Newspapers poll indicated Chiles had a 45-41 lead.

Democrat Ben Nelson led incumbent Gov. Kay Orr by 8 percentage points in a poll for November's gubernatorial election published Sunday. In a survey of 922 registered Nebraska voters conducted for the Omaha Sunday World-Herald, 44 percent said they would vote for Nelson, an Omaha attorney, and 36 percent supported Mrs. Orr, the nation's first elected Republican woman governor. Twenty percent didn't know who they would vote for or declined to answer. The margin of error was plus or minus 3 percent, the newspaper said. The polling was done last week.

Territorial Sen. Madeleine Z. Bordallo won the Democratic nomination for governor and will face Gov. Joseph Ada as she seeks to reoccupy the office her late husband lost to Ada in 1986. Mrs. Bordallo garnered 11,240 votes in Saturday's vote to defeat Lt. Gov. Rudolph G. Sablan, who had 7,511 votes. Ada, a Republican, ran unopposed and received 7,986 votes. Mrs. Bordallo, a 57-year-old Minnesota native, would become Guam's first woman governor and the first who is not a native Guamanian. She came to Guam in 1948 when her father accepted a position as a high school principal. Her husband, the late Gov. Ricardo Bordallo, was defeated by Ada in 1986 after Bordallo was indicted for witness tampering and obstruction. Last Jan. 31, Bordallo chained himself to a statue, wrapped himself in Guam's flag and fatally shot himself in the head hours before he was to fly to Los Angeles to begin serving a four-year prison term.

DOC.HEAD: Report: West African Force Takes Control Capital's Center
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS one graf for 8th `Guerrillas loyal...' to CORRECT that rival rebel leaders split six months ago sted three; pickup graf 9 `The rebels...'
DOC.TEXT: A multinational West African force in Liberia took control of the capital's center after battling rebels loyal to Charles Taylor, the Ghana News Agency reported Sunday. The news agency, which has a correspondent with the 3,000-man force, quoted Ghanaian Lt. Col. George Ayiku as saying his troops in Monrovia overcame stiff resistance from the rebels Saturday and set up heavy artillery. On Sunday, a Ghanaian ship left Monrovia with 7,000 refugees but left 5,000 others behind, the news agency said. Taylor's rebels have been accused of killing hundreds of people from the five West African nations that sent the troops to Liberia Aug. 24 to end the war, in which about 5,000 people have died. Most of those killed have been civilians. Taylor, who controls most of Liberia after eight months of civil war, opposes the five-nation force. The force has been welcomed both by the government of President Samuel Doe and a rival rebel group, who separately control portions of the capital, Monrovia. The Ghana News agency earlier reported that the task force's units had advanced beyond Spriggs Payne Airfield in eastern Monrovia in an effort to reach embassies of three of the countries contributing to the force: Ghana, Nigeria and Guinea. The other two are Gambia and Sierra Leone. Monrovia's 400,000 residents have been without water and electricity for more than two months, and food stocks were running low as all regular transport links with the outside world were cut. Guerrillas loyal to Prince Johnson, who split from Taylor six months ago, controlled Monrovia's port and most of the city center. Areas on the city's eastern fringes were under the control of Doe's troops, but were under regular attack by Taylor's fighters. The rebels accuse the Doe government of corruption and human rights abuses, but both rebels and troops have reportedly killed civilians loyal to the other side during the civil war. The government has accused Taylor of embezzlement when he served as a Doe aide. Taylor's rebels were holding several thousand Ghanaians, Nigerians and Guinean citizens. Ghanaian refugees accused the insurgents of killing at least 200 of their countrymen. Taylor has confirmed holding the foreigners, but denied that his forces had killed any. A Ghanaian merchant ship, the M.V. Tano River, sailed Sunday with 7,000 Ghanaian and other West African refugees. It was bound for the Ghanaian capital port of Accra. Two women died of malnutrition on board the ship while waiting for it to depart. Two refugees drowned while trying to climb a rope to board the ship, the news agency said, after officers said the ship could take no more passengers. At least 5,000 refugees were left behind in the port. Taylor invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24 and his fighters quickly overran most of the West African country of about 2.5 million people but were stopped on the outskirts of the capital. Johnson, who split with Taylor in February, took control of much of Monrovia but was unable to drive Doe from his heavily fortified mansion. U.S. Marines stationed on warships off Liberia have evacuated Americans and some other foreigners from Monrovia. Marines also remained posted around the U.S. Embassy. But Washington says U.S. forces will not intervene in the fighting. The five West African countries making up the task force say they are participating because they have citizens in Liberia and because 400,000 Liberian refugees are straining the resources of neighboring countries.

DOC.HEAD: Army Takes Control Of Barricade, Faces off Mohawk Militants
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS one graf for 8th `The army...' to CORRECT spelling of Kanesatake; pickup graf 9 `However, when....' ADDS two grafs with Indian reax across Canada
DOC.TEXT: The Canadian army seized control of the main Mohawk barricade in this town on Sunday without firing a shot and trapped about 30 armed men inside a small wooded area of the Kanesatake Indian territory. Seizing the main barricade at Oka, the center of an Indian uprising over land claims, effectively ended a standoff that began July 11 when Quebec provincial police launched a raid on the militants. One officer was killed, but it is not clear by whose gunfire. Lt. Col. Pierre Daigle, commander of the Canadian Forces in this sector about 20 miles west of Montreal, said Sunday he had carried out his instructions to take over the barricades and was awaiting further orders. He said there are between 350 to 450 troops and 80 armored vehicles in the Oka area. However, no fighting broke out between the soldiers and Indians, who warily watched one another for most of Sunday. Military helicopters flew over the area. Mohawk spokesman Ellen Gabriel said the Indians are ``pretty squeezed in right now. There's no way out really.'' The Mohawks fortified their positions by using a front-end loader to pile earth on a road near a two-story alcohol and drug detoxification center in the woods. After a seven-week standoff, Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa last week ordered the army to dismantle the barricades. The army moved into the Kanesatake Mohawk settlement overlooking Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal, on Saturday afternoon after factional fighting broke out between moderate and militant Mohawks. Two Indians were injured in the fighting before the army moved in. However, when the soldiers pushed forward, only one shot was fired by a Mohawk on Saturday, Daigle said. There were no casualties. Barricades set up in the Kahnawake Mohawk reserve near the Mercier bridge, south of Montreal, came down peacefully over the last few days. The barricades were set up as a sympathy protest by Mohawks there. The Warriors, a militant Mohawk organization, periodically came out from the trees and stood face-to-face with soldiers at Oka on Sunday. On one occasion, a Warrior approached a soldier, stood chest-to-chest with him and stared into his eyes as a group of reporters watched. Finally, he let out a war whoop, turned and walked away. ``I want to see their face before I kill them,'' the Warrior said. Just after 8:30 a.m., about two dozen troops backed by two armored personnel carriers, moved onto Highway 344 and began approaching the main hilltop barricade. None of the Warriors made a move to stop them. The soldiers strung barbed wire around the barricade and inspected it for booby traps. Daigle was vague about whether Warriors would be allowed to pass through his lines and leave if they so desired. The lieutenant colonel said his forces had no power of arrest. ``I have been giving orders to subordinate officers to remain in their positions and to consolidate where they are,'' he said. The uprising began when officials of the village of Oka decided to expand the local golf course onto land claimed by the Mohawks, including an Indian cemetery. That problem was solved earlier when the federal government purchased the land and said it would give it to the Indians. But the Mohawks seized the occasion to press an entire range of complaints and land claims against federal and provincial authorities. That move sparked numerous brief sympathy blockades across the country in recent weeks. At the Mercier bridge, troops cleared out the last obstructions set up seven weeks ago. There was no resistance, but officials said it would still take several days before the bridge could open to traffic. The Mercier blockade had angered residents of the south shore of the St. Lawrence River, who were forced to make long detours to get to jobs in Montreal. Across Canada, Indian leaders Sunday denounced the army operation at Oka. ``It was a bungled job all the way, right from the start, and the Mohawks are not responsible for that _ it's the federal government and the Quebec government,'' Phil Fontaine, leader of the Manitoba Assembly of Chiefs, said in Winnipeg.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis At-a-Glance
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are developments Sunday in the Persian Gulf crisis:
Forty-seven Americans flew to freedom after being held in Iraq and Kuwait. ``I wasn't a guest,'' said Lloyd Culbertson, one of those to reach Washington. ``I damned near starved to death.'' The former hostages included 24 women, 11 men and 12 children. Some said Iraqi forces may be mistreating Americans left behind.

The freed Americans were among about 700 Westerners and Japanese, mainly women and children, allowed to leave over the weekend. But thousands of others, including husbands and fathers of those freed, remained trapped in Iraq and occupied Kuwait.

In Maine, aides to President Bush said his summit with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev will likely consist of about five hours of talks devoted largely to the Persian Gulf crisis. When he announced the summit, the president said there wasn't any set agenda, and that the crisis was one of a number of issues to be addressed.

U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said he was deeply disappointed that his two days of talks in Amman, Jordan, with Iraqi's foreign minister didn't produce an agreement to defuse the crisis precipitated by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

An East German government spokesman said the country's ambassador to Kuwait was forcibly taken to Iraq on Sunday after he left his diplomatic mission, apparently to seek food at the West German Embassy.

About 12,000 mostly Arab and Asian refugees streamed from Iraq into Jordan, where tens of thousands of impoverished evacuees already languish in refugee camps. Thousands were trying to cross into Turkey and Iran.

Church services were held quietly for American soldiers in Saudi Arabia, despite the sheikdom's ban on the practice of religions other than Islam. The services were held in mess halls, tents and in warehouses.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Demonstrate On Third Anniversary Of Protester's Maiming
DOC.TEXT: About 200 people gathered on railroad tracks outside a weapons depot to protest the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf and mark the third anniversary of the accident that maimed a peace activist. Brian Willson, who lost his legs when he was hit by a train during a protest outside the Concord Naval Weapons Station, told the crowd Saturday he is outraged that weapons are still being sent from the depot to other countries. ``This is a heavy day for those of us who were here that day,'' Willson said. ``With this latest bellicose action by the U.S., it really is painful to know how barbaric we are.'' White plaster of Paris skulls and flesh-colored papier-mache legs labeled with the names of countries in conflict were put on mock coffins next to the tracks where Willson was struck on Sept. 1, 1987. Protesters have maintained a 24-hour vigil at the station since the accident. After listening to speeches and songs, demonstrators carried the coffins near the gate of the weapons station. Twenty people were arrested, cited for trespassing and released. ``Being here at Concord is to me what being next to Dachau was to the Germans,'' Willson said. ``It's a death camp.'' Another speaker was Erik Larsen, 23, of Hayward, a lance corporal in the U.S. Marine Corps Reserve who said last week he would not fight in the Middle East. ``It seems the U.S. has the types of interventions where people don't want us,'' Larsen said. ``I hope it doesn't take a bunch of body bags for people to wake up,'' Larsen said.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANMITTING TO RESTORE DROPPED GRAF MARK
Hundreds of Hostages Freed; Iraq Would `Eat Mud'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Saddam's government saying it would eat mud rather than yield, landing permission denied to flights; ADDS report that $1 million in cash also stolen by Iraqis; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AMM2
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of Americans returned to freedom Sunday in the first major airlift of Westerners from Iraq during the month-old Persian Gulf crisis, but Saddam Hussein's government remained defiant and vowed to ``eat mud'' before yielding. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, who held two days of talks in Amman, Jordan with the Iraqi foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, said he was ``deeply disappointed'' with the outcome. ``What Iraq wants is to stay in Kuwait, which is unacceptable to the international community, to the U.N. Security Council and to its secretary-general,'' Perez de Cuellar told reporters in Paris Sunday. Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev and President Bush are to discuss the gulf crisis and other issues Sept. 9 in Helsinki, Finland. But even following the weekend announcement of the superpower summit, some leaders warned a speedy resolution was unlikely. ``We have to settle down for a long haul, which will require a good deal of steady determination on the part of all concerned,'' said British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd. For the freed hostages, joy and relief upon reaching safety was muted by fears for those left behind. Saddam, the Iraqi president, is using captive foreigners as human shields to protect key Iraqi installations against potential attack by the U.S.-led multinational force deployed in the region. About 21,000 Westerners, including 3,000 Americans, were stranded in Iraq and Kuwait by the Aug. 2 invasion. A chartered Iraqi Airways Boeing 747, carrying more than 300 Westerners, arrived in Washington on Sunday after stopovers in Paris and London. It left Baghdad on Saturday along with two other planeloads of foreigners. Among those arriving in Britain was Stuart Lockwood, the 5-year-old British boy whose hair was tousled by Saddam in a television encounter with a group of Western hostages last month. The sight of a smiling Saddam clasping the uncomfortable-looking child brought expressions of revulsion from Western leaders. Stuart arrived home Sunday with his mother and brother, but his father was still being held. The flight continued on to Washington, and the 47 weary Americans arrived at Dulles International Airport outside the capital after 24 hours of travel. One of the arrivals, 76-year-old Lloyd Culbertson of El Paso, Texas, was asked if the hostages left behind feared for their lives. ``Yes, they certainly do,'' he said. At Tokyo's international airport, 68 Japanese women and children arriving on a Japan Air Lines flight were greeted by tearful relatives and friends, a day after leaving Iraq. Japan welcomed their release but expressed fears for 344 of its nationals still in Iraq. A Lufthansa plane with 250 women and 61 children on board _ including 60 Americans and 71 Germans _ landed early Sunday in Frankfurt, West Germany, after leaving Baghdad late Saturday. A few arriving passengers smiled briefly or waved, but nearly all looked grim and exhausted. The airlifts came after Saddam, in what he called a humanitarian gesture, announced last week that women and children among the foreign captives would be allowed to leave Iraq. However, the departure of several hundred more Western women and children from Baghdad was apparently delayed as Iraq withheld landing clearance for two special flights from Britain and France. If permission is not granted, a British Foreign Office spokesman said hostages could return home on Iraqi Airways, even though regularly scheduled flights by the Iraqi carrier are banned under the U.N. trade embargo. Western governments have demanded the release of all the hostages, and denounced Iraq's footdragging in freeing the women and children as promised. Confirming previous reports that Iraq had begun to ration food, government spokesman Naji Al-Hadithi said in Baghdad, ``We have a war-tested society. We have a war-tested economy. So even if we eat mud, we will resist pressure and not kneel down to any foreign power.'' Iraq fought Iran in an 8-year-war that ended in 1988. At the same meeting with reporters, Culture Minister Latif Nasaif Jasim declared, ``We need only bread and water. We need no more than that. We can live for a long time. ``Dignity is more important than food,'' he added. Britain's Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher heaped scorn on Saddam over the hostage-holding, calling him ``a person who has taken hostages, cruelly, brutally, and a person who has hidden behind the skirts of women and children.'' ``This man is a loser,'' she said in an interview aired Sunday on Britain's TV-AM network. The official Iraqi News Agency responded by calling the prime minister an ``old hag.'' In occupied Kuwait, hardships intensified at embassies defying an Iraqi order to close their doors. Many missions are without power and water, surrounded by troops, and the skeleton staffs operating the missions are virtual prisoners. A diplomatic source in Brussels said Sunday the East German ambassador was picked up by Iraqi authorities and taken to Baghdad. He had ventured out of his embassy, where food and water were running low, to visit the West German mission. In other developments Sunday: _Iraqi officials told foreign reporters who arrived in the country before Aug. 27 that they must leave on or before next Tuesday. A government spokesman told the reporters they were being asked to leave to make room for other foreign journalists who were awaiting entry visas. _Two U.S. cargo ships entered the Suez Canal on their way to the Persian Gulf, a canal official said. They will join around 30 U.S. ships in the region, including three aircraft carriers, a battleship armed with Tomakawk crusie missile, more than one dozen missile cruisers, destroyers and supply ships. _Kuwaiti officials said that Iraq plundered $2 billion worth of Kuwaiti gold and cash, as well as 15 Kuwait Airways planes when it invaded. The allegations appeared in the British weekly Observer newspaper, which interviewed several exiled Kuwaiti leaders in Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Hostages Get Red, White and Blue Welcome Home
With AM-Gulf-Americans Home
DOC.TEXT: Two of the 47 Americans freed from captivity in Iraq and Kuwait got a red, white and blue welcome home Sunday from tearful friends, neighbors and relatives in Milwaukee, and another celebrated her 16th birthday at home. ``Long live America!'' 16-year-old Sayyeda Mirza's father, Masood, said after he, his daughter and his wife arrived at New York City's La Guardia Airport on the last leg of their journey to their Manhasset Hills, N.Y., home. The 24 women, 11 men and 12 children returned to America when their Iraqi jetliner landed at Washington-Dulles International Airport outside Washington after a 24-hour journey from Baghdad. They were among hundreds of foreigners, mostly women and children allowed to leave Iraq last week. The freed hostages gave varying accounts of their treatment. One told of a candlelight champagne birthday dinner for her daughter at the Baghdad hotel where she was held; a man who was at the besieged U.S. Embassy in Kuwait said he ``damned near starved to death.'' The joy of homecoming was dampened by fear for those left behind. About 21,000 Westerners, including 3,000 Americans, were stranded in Iraq and Kuwait following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is using some of the captives as human shields to protect key installations. Mirza said that when he learned he was being released, ``I was happy. I was crying. ``And the next moment I thought, `What about the others?' '' Mirza, who is of Indian descent, his wife Nasreen and daughter were vacationing in London when they decided on the spur of the moment to visit Islamic holy sites in Baghdad. He said Sunday he didn't know why his family was allowed to go home. Prabhavathi Murikpudi, 40, wept with joy when she and her 10-year-old daughter, Sylaja, were met at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport by her husband, whose monthlong effort to gain their release included a videotaped plea sent to Saddam. The Murikpudis drove back to their Milwaukee home, where they were greeted by dozens of friends, neighbors and relatives. Their home was decorated with red, white and blue streamers and ``Welcome Home'' banners. Mrs. Murikipudi and her daughter were detained by the Iraqis on Aug. 2 while their airliner was being refueled in Kuwait. They had been on a trip to visit relatives in India. Mrs. Murikipudi said the tension reached its peak during the ordeal's first few days. ``They were fighting on the runway, and we were told to get off the plane and to get into the airport,'' she said. She and her daughter were taken with other Westerners from an airport hotel to the southern Iraqi city of Basra, then Baghdad and later a fertilizer plant about 225 miles from Baghdad. They were returned to Baghdad on Aug. 30. ``We were treated excellent, but we were always with guards,'' Mrs. Murikipudi said. ``I had no complaints ...'' Sylaja celebrated her 10th birthday while in Iraq. Mrs. Murikipudi said other hostages and employees of the Al-Rashid Hotel where they were staying tried to make the best of it. ``Some ladies mentioned (her birthday) to the cook and they arranged a big celebration,'' including champagne, music, gifts and a candlelight dinner, she said. ``We were really treated very well, physically,'' Mrs. Mirza told television station WCBS-TV in an interview at the family's Manhasset Hills home. But Lloyd Culbertson, who was at the embassy in Kuwait, told a different story, and disagreed with the Iraqi characterization of the captive foreigners as guests. ``I wasn't a guest,'' said the 76-year-old El Paso man. ``I damned near starved to death.'' Culbertson, who said he had taught electronics to the Kuwaiti military for 5{ years, said hostages in the embassy had no fresh water or electrical power and were fast using up food supplies. ``The people are starving in that embassy, or they soon will be,'' Culbertson told reporters during a short layover at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. He said at Dulles that meals at the embassy were ``pretty skimpy rations'' _ mainly frozen turkey. ``I have never eaten so much turkey in my life.''

DOC.HEAD: First Air Force Crash Victim Returned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `The remains...' with hometown of victim
DOC.TEXT: The body of an officer killed in the crash of an Air Force cargo jet in West Germany was flown here Sunday, the first victim to be returned to the United States. The remains of Capt. Bradley R. Schuldt, of Arlington Heights, Ill., arrived at Dover Air Force Base on a C-5 cargo jet from Rhein Main Air Base near Frankfurt. Schuldt was among 13 Air Force personnel killed when their C-5 crashed shortly after takeoff from Ramstein Air Base on Wednesday. Four others were injured. Air Force officials said there were no plans to hold honors ceremonies here for any of the crash victims. The base mortuary will prepare the body for burial before it is transferred to next of kin, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Gustav Speeds Toward Canada's Eastern Tip
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Gustav accelerated toward the eastern tip of Canada on Sunday with top sustained winds near 70 mph, forecasters said. At 10:30 p.m. EDT, Gustav was centered near 47.1 degrees north latitude and 45.8 degrees west longitude, about 360 miles east of Cape Race, Newfoundland, according to the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. Gustav was moving north northeast at about 30 mph with tropical storm force winds extending up to 230 miles from its center. It was expected to accelerate while losing some strength before Tuesday, hurricane specialist Max Mayfield said. Gustav reached top winds of 100 mph Saturday before dropping below hurricane-force winds of 74 mph Sunday, forecasters said. The Atlantic hurricane season lasts from June 1 to November 30.

DOC.HEAD: For Bush, the Enemy at Home Is Impatience
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Substitutes for the regular column by Walter R. Mears, vacationing
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: For George Bush, the easy part is over. So far, he has only had to cope with Saddam Hussein. Congress is back in town next week. The president got a glimpse of the shape of things to come if he checked on what was said afterward by the 170 members of Congress who interrupted their vacations for a presidential update on the Persian Gulf showdown. Bush appealed for bipartisan support, and he got it, effusively. But there was an uneasy undertone after the session that suggested criticism is lurking _ especially if the deployment turns into a stalemate. Stalemate is the best Bush can hope for _ it beats war _ while he waits for the international quarantine of Iraq to work. But American public opinion is not so good at waiting. Not if the price of gasoline keeps rising and the economy keeps sinking. Not if television carries pictures of Kuwaitis on the French Riviera driving to rallies in their Mercedes Benz automobiles to cheer on the American boys. Not if American women soldiers _ on full television display in soldierly roles for the first time _ run afoul of cultural differences in a Saudi society that gives women scant status and no equality. Bush can stand the heat from Congress, but if the American people turn against this enterprise they can ultimately end it. That was Vietnam's lesson for policymakers. Mark Mellman, a Democratic pollster, guesses Bush has a fairly short period. ``If we just keep 200,000 troops in the Saudi desert without them having any clear goals other than deterrence, I think his support will dissipate fairly quickly,'' Mellman says. ``It may be 60 days, it may be 90 days, it may be six months, but we don't have something happen by Christmas, I'd guess support will dissipate.'' ``Americans are impatient by and large and goal-oriented and success-oriented,'' he added. ``This represents a tremendous financial commitment and an emotional commitment and for many people a real hardship.'' Political scientist Dick Barody of Stanford University, a student of public opinion, says he is still mystified over whether public opinion leads the politicians or vice versa. ``People who want to do other things with the money will begin to portray this as a war-that-isn't and a foreign policy that isn't getting us anywhere,'' Barody says. At the end in Vietnam, the public could no longer stomach the war and Congress responded by refusing to appropriate money for any purpose there other than to bring home the troops. After hearing from Bush last week, lawmakers did not directly challenge his decision to confront Saddam Hussein. When politicians want to be critical of a policy that appears popular, they attack it from the fringes rather than frontally. That's what happened. _They complained that while Bush has rallied the world's support for isolating Saddam, the venture is still largely an American undertaking. ``If we don't watch it, we'll have a 90 or 95 percent share of the on-the-ground troops,'' said Rep. David Obey, D-Wis. ``I don't think that's politically sustainable at home.'' Rep. David Bonior, D-Mich., said his constituents already are complaining that the Japanese, the Australians and others are not doing enough. Rep. Christopher Smith, R-N.J., added the Soviets to the list. _They said Bush had failed to articulate America's purpose. They said he had to specify the nature of the threat to the U.S. national interest. Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., told Bush directly, participants reported, that lawmakers like himself who came of age during Vietnam want to know ``what we're doing in Saudi Arabia.'' Rep. Mike DeWine, R-Ohio, said it was time for Bush to get on television and put before the country ``not only our specific objective ... but the rationale and the reasoning behind those objectives.'' Sen. John H. Chafee, R-R.I., said Bush owed his countrymen ``as fine an explanation of our presence as can be produced.'' _And they criticized the administration for failing to develop a policy that would make the country less dependent on foreign oil. Rep. Norm Dicks, D-Wash., said some pointed out to Bush that he hadn't even brought his energy secretary, James Watkins, to the meeting. None of that is direct criticism of what Bush has done in standing up to Saddam. There will be none if he succeeds. But in this situation, stalemate is not success. Dicks said that erosion of public support is inevitable. ``Already, there are people asking, `Why is it we are out there?'' he said. ``Is it just because of cheap oil?''
